interested spending month scotland sure go!
i single 34 year old female, currently working remotely ability anywhere thought nice explore new place. convenience city walkable town (i vehicle, unless inexpensive rental options aware of!) i'd opportunity meet locals age, check surrounding area bit, hang local pub. idea slightly smaller city/town thought people friendlier easier meet people within short period, wrong - want end somewhere sleepy everyone much older filled families.
i love ocean places inland long there's natural beauty, that's deal breaker. mostly want new place new friends.
any suggestions appreciated!
column5:
i am interested in spending a month in scotland but not sure where to go!
i am a single 34 year old female, currently working remotely with the ability to be anywhere and thought it would be nice to explore a new place. i like the convenience of a city or a walkable town (i won't have a vehicle, unless there are inexpensive rental options i am not aware of!) i'd like the opportunity to meet some locals around my age, check out the surrounding area a bit, and hang in a local pub. i like the idea of a slightly smaller city/town because i have a thought that people will be friendlier and it would be easier to meet people within a short period, but i may be wrong about that - i don't want to end up somewhere sleepy where everyone is much older than i am or filled with families.
i love being by the ocean but also like places that are inland as long as there's a bit of natural beauty, so that's not a deal breaker. i mostly just want to get to know a new place and make some new friends.
any suggestions are appreciated!
column8: Where to spend a month in Scotland?

column4:
>>akasaka inconvenient base tokyo sightseeing.
i disagree.
via subway station akasaka-mitsuke, access subway lines (3 lines serving nearby nagatacho station connected via underground pass) sightseeing spots tokyo within 30 min various directions. downside served jr commuter trains limo bus hnd. that's normally recommend 1st-time visitors.
for me, tokyo monorail (rapid trains) hnd hamamatsucho direct 20 min, change taxi akasaka 15 20 min.
ps. stayed akasaka roughly 10 times business trips 98 2002. subsequent those, stayed 6-8 times personal trips. frequently meet local friends plenty nice local western restaurants, apart nice hotels.
column5:
>>akasaka is inconvenient base to do tokyo sightseeing.
i disagree.
via the subway station akasaka-mitsuke, one may access to 5 subway lines (3 lines serving nearby nagatacho station connected via an underground pass) which can take you to most sightseeing spots in tokyo within 30 min in various directions. the downside is that it's not served by any jr commuter trains and limo bus from hnd. that's why i normally don't recommend to 1st-time visitors.
for me, i always take the tokyo monorail (rapid trains) from hnd to hamamatsucho direct in 20 min, then change taxi to akasaka in another 15 to 20 min.
ps. have stayed in akasaka roughly 10 times in my business trips from 98 to 2002. subsequent to those, have stayed there about another 6-8 times on personal trips. i frequently meet my local friends there with plenty of nice local and western restaurants, apart from some nice hotels.

column5:
nlgirl06,
sorry to say...i also believe it is not possible for foreigners to enter japan this june 2021. but it is not clear on your note. if you are holding a japanese passport or residency pass, then certainly you may enter. but the 14 days quarantine isolation should be part of your plan as global has already mentioned.
again, it is not clear in your note. are you referring to a budget of $110 in us dollar? the currency is in yen. but if in us dollar, that amount will be appropriate for food/restaurant budget for two persons per day. it will not be enough for accommodations and/or transportation. of the three elements, transportation is the most expensive element in japan personally speaking.
do some more research before booking your flight tickets in early june as planned.

column4:
fly tokyo first, change order visit face many long train bus rides long flight. spend initial days tokyo work way kansai. end trip, fly osaka home via tokyo airport transit necessary.
ramen everywhere. places decent enough job. ones high marks often see long lines--not necessarily worth effort.
sushi: agree toyosu worth all. tsukiji outer market sushi restaurants well small eats. much interesting place wander 1/2 day. normal times, becomes crowded 10am early can. average, find chains tsukiji serve slightly quality items places. course, look reviews book famous places parts tokyo quality whole experience could better.
tokyo, osaka large cities good places yakiniku (grilled meat). sure try couple times. necessarily top wagyu enjoy experience.
finally, december iffy best visit point. lot depends japanese vaccination rate whether japan feels foreign country visitors bring cases. commit anything can't refund.
column5:
if you have to fly into tokyo first, then i would change the order of visit so you don't have to face so many long train or bus rides after a long flight. spend the initial days at tokyo and work your way to kansai. at the end of your trip, fly out of osaka and go home via a tokyo airport transit if necessary.
ramen is everywhere. most places do a decent enough job. the ones that get very high marks often see long lines--not necessarily worth the effort.
sushi: i agree toyosu is not worth it at all. tsukiji outer market has sushi restaurants as well as other small eats. it's a much more interesting place to wander for 1/2 day. during normal times, it becomes very crowded after 10am so go early if you can. on average, i do find that even the chains around tsukiji serve slightly better quality items than some other places. of course, you can look at reviews and book some of the famous places at other parts of tokyo where quality and the whole experience could be better.
tokyo, osaka and other large cities also have very good places for yakiniku (grilled meat). be sure to try it a couple of times. you don't necessarily have to go for the top wagyu to enjoy the experience.
finally, december is iffy at best to visit at this point. a lot depends on the japanese vaccination rate by then but also whether japan feels foreign country visitors would bring in more cases. don't commit to anything if you can't get a refund.

column5:
hello everyone.
sorry this is so long.
i am planning a trip to thailand for the month of november 2022, (surely we will be good to go by then right?). i am so excited just thinking about travelling i want to ask your opinion on my plan.
i am 67 and my husband 72. i have been in various countries in south east asia, and in thailand 3 times. my husband has never been.
so this is the plan so far (open to critique, comments and suggestions)
i will have been in bali for the month of october with a friend and then flying to bangkok to meet up with hubby. overnight at the airport hotel
fly to siem reap for four nights. i have been , husband and friend have not. see the temples, ton le sap lake at sunset and a dance show. anyone recommend a good show?
looking for a mid range hotel with a pool walking distance to the market etc if you have a favourite.
from there fly to chaing mai for six nights . again i have been, others have not. we want to go to an elephant sanctuary (any recommendations?) a cooking class and sightsee lots of temples.
perhaps a trip up to chaing rai, (is it worth it? haven’t been) perhaps add another day to overnight there?
the yee peng lantern festival will be happening so thinking of going to the university for the first night to see it, and looking for recommendations for a roof top restaurant /bar for the second night.
any hints on chaing mai would be appreciated. i will want to stay in the old city.
i will also get another thai silk jacket made if i can. i had one made there 15 years ago and it was amazing. i lost too much weight to wear it any more. which is good and bad. anyone recommend a good reasonable tailor who has actual thai silk . i had one made in vietnam a couple years ago but it was a silk polyester blend i think and not the same.
my friend will go home at this point and husband and i will maybe head to khao sok for four nights, thinking of jungle house.
is that too much time, not enough? i read of another place where the cabins are on the water and you can kayak right off them but cant find that. any one know what it is called?
would i want to stay a couple of nights at each place?
will it be really hot, muggy and buggy there in november? my husband does not do well with extreme mugginess and heat.
then the beach!! phi phi for 8 nights to relax, read, swim and snorkel. i stayed at phi phi relax last time, this time though i think i will stay in one of their beachfront cabins so as to avoid all of those stairs.
or open to any other recommendations of similar places. we like to walk out the door and swim in the ocean.
then railay beach for 5 nights . i cant believe how much the prices have gone up since i was there 4 years ago! thinking of railay village resort but open to suggestions. last time we stayed at sand sea but the price has gone up so much.
i am not planning to spend any time in bangkok on purpose.i have been twice before and don’t need to go back other than overnights for flights.
i can add a few more days if you think there is something else that is a must do, close to where we will be so not adding too much travel time
i loved koh samui but from what i have read november is not the best time to travel there.
i look forward to any suggestions from you. this is my favourite part , the planning of it all. i am so excited.
thank you in advance for your expertise and experiences.

column4:
practice, locals koh samui phuket large numbers islands far away drive weekends.
koh samui airport island's airline held private ownership. owners maximise profits (as expected) maximise public interest koh samui.
a significant amount hotel, restaurants, bars, nightclubs built international tourist markets domestic market. simply function market islands targeted.
i koh samui couple months ago number star resorts amazing, thought target market entire world, number star resorts surprising.
the tourist infrastructure islands designed built international tourist markets local tourist market. simply fact. re-opened international tourist markets rest country. islands suffered much economically.
column5:
i think in practice, locals don't go to koh samui and phuket in large numbers because the islands are too far away to drive for weekends.
koh samui airport and the island's only airline are also held in private ownership. the owners maximise their own profits (as expected) and do not maximise the public interest of koh samui.
a significant amount of the hotel, restaurants, bars, nightclubs etc are built for the international tourist markets and not the domestic market. that is simply a function of the market that the islands targeted.
i was on koh samui a couple of months ago and the number 5 star resorts was amazing, but then i thought if the target market was the entire world, then the number of 5 star resorts is not that surprising.
the tourist infrastructure on the islands was designed and built for the international tourist markets and not for local tourist market. that is simply a fact. that is why they are being re-opened to the international tourist markets before the rest of the country. that is why the islands have suffered so much economically.

column4:
hi, personally i’d ubud first, gili t, kuta. kuta closer airport departure flight.
why interest seminyak? i’m personally fan kuta prefer seminyak. metered taxis plentiful economical visit seminyak kuta want wander around. favourite sanur. sanur half hour boat trip across island nusa lembongan/nusa penida you’re interested water activities (not necessarily diving snorkelling) stay days.
think nights gili long. me, ubud deserves longer stay nights (2 full days) plenty see ubud town good base sightseeing cultural sites/experiences afield. could walk campuhan ridge ubud. you’ve stated “replanning” you’ve done research chosen areas. perhaps read pinned posts top forum “the different areas bali.....”.
the weather less wet according crystal ball tell hot humid. june lovely time visit. july/august/september popular time room rates higher busy.
eating bali excellent. many, many cafes/restaurants/local warungs cuisines prices suit budgets.
these comments pre covid.
column5:
hi, personally i’d go to ubud first, then gili t, then kuta. kuta being closer to the airport for your departure flight.
why your interest in seminyak? i’m personally not a fan of kuta and prefer seminyak. metered taxis are plentiful and economical for you to visit seminyak from kuta if you want to have a wander around. and my other favourite is sanur. from sanur you can go for a half hour boat trip across to the island of nusa lembongan/nusa penida if you’re interested in water activities (not necessarily diving but maybe snorkelling) and stay for a few days.
think 6 nights on gili t too long. for me, ubud deserves a longer stay than 3 nights (2 full days) as there is plenty to see and do in ubud town and a good base for sightseeing cultural sites/experiences further afield. you could walk the campuhan ridge in ubud. as you’ve stated your “replanning” it would suggest you’ve already done the research of your chosen areas. perhaps have another read of the pinned posts at the top of the forum “the different areas of bali.....”.
the weather will be less wet according to my crystal ball but i can tell you it will be very hot and humid. june is a lovely time to visit. july/august/september is the most popular time but room rates are higher and very busy.
eating out in bali is excellent. many, many cafes/restaurants/local warungs with all cuisines and prices to suit all budgets.
these comments are pre covid.

column4:

lovely, relatively unspoiled, less crowded beaches - north / middle andaman find less people!
some best scuba diving sites india
the gateway middle north andaman - baratang - reaching experience - drive dense tropical forest - tribal reserve (you allowed step vehicle) - chance see jarawa tribal people (hunter,gatherer tribes dont want ‘civilized’ lead blissful life oldest tribes historically)
30 minute boat ride breathtaking mangroves - something see nat geo! trek forest see limestone caves
boat ride creeks watch 100s parrots reach parrot island - night time home
ross & smith islands connected sandbar disappears high tide
turtle nesting sites (during nesting season)
the famous radhanagar beach havelock
watersports havelock, neil, northbay
coral watching jollybuoy / redskin
history: cellular jail british imprisoned tortured indian freedom fighters, japanese bunkers, remnants british rule ross island (this different ross & smith), sound light shows both
i on, highlights. beware - facilities developing top notch - reason relatively unspoiled!
hopefully time travel, london - chennai direct flights resumed connecting flight there. (port blair international airport open soon direct flights!)
depending interests plan. idea
1 full day visiting cellular jail,samudrika marine museum, anthropological museum, chatham saw mill (if interests you) sunset watch trip chidiya tapu
1 full day northbay (sea walking) ross island
1 full day jolly buoy - coral viewing see combine mount harriet trek afternoon
3-4 full nights havelock enjoying beaches, scuba, sea walking, snorkelling etc
2-3 nights neil island
1 day baratang
3-4 nights north andaman - ross & smith, full day saddle peak trek, aam kunj beach etc

column5:
andaman is definitely a great destination. it is not just about beaches and offers a lot of different things.
lovely, relatively unspoiled, less crowded beaches - if you go to north / middle andaman you may find even less people!
some of the best scuba diving sites in india
the gateway to middle and north andaman - baratang - reaching here is an experience - drive through dense tropical forest - it is also a tribal reserve (you are not allowed to step out of your vehicle) - chance to see jarawa tribal people (hunter,gatherer tribes who dont want to be ‘civilized’ and probably lead a very blissful life and one of the oldest tribes historically)
30 minute boat ride through breathtaking mangroves - something like what you see in nat geo! then trek through forest to see the limestone caves
boat ride through creeks to watch 100s of parrots reach parrot island - their night time home
ross & smith islands that are connected by a sandbar that disappears during high tide
turtle nesting sites (during the nesting season)
the famous radhanagar beach in havelock
watersports in havelock, neil, northbay
coral watching at jollybuoy / redskin
history: cellular jail where british imprisoned and tortured indian freedom fighters, japanese bunkers, remnants of british rule in ross island (this is different from ross & smith), sound and light shows at both
i can go on, but these are some highlights. but beware - facilities are still developing and may not be top notch - may be the reason why it is relatively unspoiled!
hopefully by the time you travel, london - chennai direct flights would have resumed and take a connecting flight from there. (port blair international airport will open soon and you may even have direct flights!)
depending on your interests you can plan. just to give you an idea
1 full day visiting cellular jail,samudrika marine museum, anthropological museum, chatham saw mill (if that interests you) and a sunset watch trip chidiya tapu
1 full day for northbay (sea walking) and ross island
1 full day for jolly buoy - coral viewing and see if you can combine a mount harriet trek in the afternoon
3-4 full nights in havelock enjoying the beaches, scuba, sea walking, snorkelling etc
2-3 nights in neil island
1 day for baratang
3-4 nights for north andaman - ross & smith, 1 full day for saddle peak trek, aam kunj beach etc
there is another great option - if so much of travel is not for you - spend a week in havelock in a resort either on the radhanagar or vijaynagar beaches and about 5 nights in the neil islands and just the night of arrival and night before departure in port blair town!
ps: to reach havelock and neil - you have to take ferries. for baratang, north andaman - you travel by road. self drive cars are not available in andaman, you have to hire a cab with driver

column4:

i look carefully ticket t's c's event need cancel - issues covered law, others not, airlines offer flexibility others policies.
column5:
set up a 'prive change alert' on a site like skyscanner or kayak.....this wi give you a very good idea of how prices are moving, day to day, week to week.
i would say that you should also look very carefully at the ticket t's and c's in the event you need to cancel - some issues are covered by law, others not, but some airlines offer more flexibility than others in their policies.

any thoughts much appreciated!
thank you,
amy

column5:
if you’ve been to dubai before then you’ll be aware of the standard of driving.... if you feel comfortable then go for it, i drove in dubai for years but i no longer do as the ever changing roads just give me a headache.
my husband drives now when we are there but he does find it stressful at times.
also be mindful if you go anywhere with outdoor parking, getting into a boiling hot car in the summer in dubai that’s been standing a few hours is no fun. touching the seatbelts and steering wheel even less so!!!
i understand your concern re safety as i’m quite paranoid when it comes to covid & germs in general but i think dubai rta has quite stringent measures in place re hygiene. i’m unsure if there’s still a maximum number of passengers allowed, if so then you might need two taxis but if you’re sitting in the back with a face mask on and sanitising your hands after touching seat belts, doors etc i think you’d feel okay but it’s obviously a personal choice.
in all honesty if & when i get to travel anywhere this year i plan to do little in terms of sightseeing and avoid crowds, transport as much as i can but there’s the obvious hurdle of the flight & airport...
edited: 7:02 am, april 25, 2021

column4:
difficult build entire itinerary repeating places. quick thoughts weeks assuming fly in/out tokyo:
1-3 tokyo settle, rid jet lag, perhaps day trip kamakura/enoshima kawaguchiko
4-9 fly regional airport eastern hokkaido train way sapporo snow festival. see thread hokkaido ideas
10-15 fly osaka. osaka kyoto base days. day trip option 1) okayama + kurashiki; 2) koyasan (can overnight trip); 3) himeji + kobe; 4) kinosaki onsen (best overnight trip), stop amanohashidate way back; 5) nara (if visited previously). 15, train takayama late afternoon (maximize daylight hours) arrive evening.
16 takayama + shin-hotaka ropeway
17 shirakawago morning, kanazawa afternoon stay overnight there
18 kanazawa full day, train tokyo later evening
19-21 tokyo, toss nikko day trip chill tokyo
edited: 10:35 pm, 25,
column5:
it's difficult to build an entire itinerary without repeating some places. quick thoughts for 3 weeks assuming you have to fly in/out of tokyo:
1-3 tokyo to settle, get rid of jet lag, perhaps take a day trip to kamakura/enoshima or kawaguchiko
4-9 fly to a regional airport to eastern hokkaido and train your way down to sapporo for snow festival. see your other thread for hokkaido ideas
10-15 fly to osaka. use either osaka or kyoto as your base for a few days. day trip option 1) okayama + kurashiki; 2) koyasan (can be an overnight trip); 3) himeji + kobe; 4) kinosaki onsen (best as an overnight trip), can stop at amanohashidate on way back; 5) nara (if you haven't visited previously). on 15, take train to takayama in the late afternoon (maximize daylight hours) to arrive in the evening.
16 takayama + shin-hotaka ropeway
17 shirakawago morning, kanazawa afternoon and stay overnight there
18 kanazawa full day, train to tokyo later in the evening
19-21 tokyo, toss in a nikko day trip if you like or just chill at tokyo
edited: 10:35 pm, may 25, 2021

column5:
hi,
these “green zones” have only been mooted and exactly how they will work is unknown.
our trips to bali always include amed then often include places like gilis, nusa lembongan or pemuteran. sometimes ubud and somewhere “down south” before flying home.
we mainly go for diving, snorkeling and chillaxing.
we had a trip for november 2020 which was ubud - amed - gili t - nusa lembongan - sanur (before flying to perth/rottnes island). obviously cancelled.
our next trip, whenever, hopefully will be as above but without oz.
we will not go to bali (when allowed) if we are restricted to places we have little or no interest in staying.
however bali is not open to international tourists and nobody knows when it will be open, who will be first or entry criteria (whether -ve test and/or covid vaccine and/or quarantine) or where you will be allowed to stay.
you also have to take into account all your flight transit countries. even if bali opens it is possible your transit countries may not allow you in even for transit (as happened with singapore last year who banned many countries even from transit).
the irony is that china may be one of the first countries to have some sort of “travel corridor” agreement with indonesia.

column5:
>>all the articles list the whole loop taking 6-8 hours.
that might include travels b/w tokyo and hakone yumoto - at the foothills of hakone. the odakyu train serving b/w shinjuku and hakone yumoto direct takes well over 1 hour, though cheaper than by shinkansen.
however, the hakone loop alone takes roughly 4 hours - excluding visits to museums etc. if you arrive at odawara before 11am, there is ample time to complete a full loop.
ps. i used to visit hakone on weekends when staying in tokyo on business trips.
edited: 2:13 am, june 06, 2021

column5:
hello! we jumped on one of the cheap tokyo flight deals for november with the expectation that we will likely have to push the trip further out... but in the meantime, i love researching and planning trips, and here i am digging through tripadvisor again!
we did an amazing 2 weeks in japan in november 2019 and covered all of the major first-timer places: tokyo, kamakura/enoshima, kyoto, nara, osaka, himeji, hiroshima/miyajima, fukuoka (sumo tournament/nanzoin buddha). disneysea.
now i'm looking for advice on what to do for a second trip! we love doing a bit of everything - covering the most famous stuff, pretty temples/gardens (especially if we are there for fall leaves) again, easy hikes, eating, and just wandering. my husband does japanese calligraphy as a hobby, so we're also looking for museums/classes/shops for his interests.
we are planning to do hakone/mt. fuji area and a few days around kyoto/osaka because there is so much to see and do there (i really want to do the aquarium!). and in my research, i've recently discovered the "diamond route" term for fukushima, ibaraki, and tochigi prefectures. since nikko is definitely a place i want to go this time, i was wondering if the other locations are worth spending 3-4 days exploring, something like: tokyo > mito > koriyama > urabandai > aizu-wakamatsu > ouchijuku > nikko > utsunomiya > tokyo?
we would do this ourselves on trains/buses, not through a tour company, but here are example itineraries to illustrate what i'm thinking: 
so any other advice for our second trip itinerary?
days 1-2 tokyo
3-7 diamond route? or just a nikko day trip and then go somewhere else?
8-11 kyoto/osaka - other day trips besides nara to do?
12-14 hakone/mt. fuji
15 tokyo and return flight
thanks for your help!

thanh toan bridge, recently undergone restoration work, 7km town vast rice paddies. right beside small market small rice growing museum nearby. relaxing place.

column5:
ten days is not too long. you list 10 nights in the three cities, but if you are travelling from and back to hcmc on days and 10, isn't that only 9 nights?
i suggest flying to hue and back from danang (or vice versa) to have one less 'moving day', checking in and out of accommodation - unless you already plan to go by rail one way and road the other between danang and hue.
in hue, the imperial citadel is worth a visit and with no large international tour groups around you shouldn't find it crowded. cycling is easy around the citadel and between there and thien mu pagoda in the leafy streets and garden houses of kim long. it is cooler there than the citadel and central area of the city. you can find good local food and cafes in both areas.
outside the city, distances make a motorcycle or car a better choice. it will also be very very hot in july.
some suggestions:
huyen tran princess temple. i've never seen many there. past the top building to the left are stone steps to the peace bell and good views worth the climb.
dong khanh and gia long tombs receive fewer visitors than the three tombs on most itineraries. they are all worth a visit but two or three is enough for most on one day.
thanh toan bridge, which has recently undergone restoration work, is 7km out of town through vast rice paddies. it is right beside a small market and a small rice growing museum is nearby. a relaxing place.
thuan an beach will be busy before 9 am and after 4pm and quiet in between. along the way from the city i like to stop at cho no, a riverside market. futher on you could detour a little to chuon lagoon. if you want to venture south from there - over 25km more - you'll find an bang aka city of ghosts with its hundreds of extravagant ornate tombs. there is a shorter route back via phu bai.
if you aren't renting a motorbike, a motorbike tour rider or private car driver will take to to places you request, but i can't recommend any at the moment. all the riders i've used have found new jobs. the drivers i've used were sole operators and some have had to sell their cars. others decided not to continue to register it as a business car carrying the new yellow plates. maybe they will return sometime. meanwhile, they too have other work. your hotel will probably know who is available.
regards
rayza

column5:
>>the layover can be from 12 to 15 hours involving an overnight stay<<
so first off the layover structure. you will be able to buy separate tickets in and out, but you won' be able to fly them at the moment. as such, you need an airside transit only option - so a single ticket on one of the permitted airlines/airline pairings.
>>can someone share info if there is hotel open during the covid-19 pandemic. if not, what airport facilities within the air side can help getting some reasonable sleep also getting some meals, may be a shower?<<
there are two of the airside transit hotels open at the moment.
you dont mention where you are flying from and that has the potential to be important. if you are flying in from most locations then you get escorted to the hotel for the stay and then shuffled to a transit holding area. from there you can order food on an app, use vending machines but otherwise you are sat in a fixed, potentially crowded area.
if you are coming from australia, new zealand, brunei or mainland china then you have more freedom and there are more things open and accessible.
this thread discussed what it is like for those allowed to wander a bit more due to their point of origin

changi airport's covid transit guide

singapore airlines transit guide for changi (lists a more up to date set of airlines that can be used)

column5:
i presume the bounce in singapore is to avoid a through flight to australia where you would have to present both passports to the indonesian officials thus causing you problems with their jealous passport? or are you young enough to still be allowed dual passports in indonesia? if the latter, just do as described above - or even step back a bit and enter singapore on the aus passport details.
otherwise while very rare to be spotted and intervened upon (countries tend not to want to police this sort of thing unless its also an issue to themselves), if you present both passports to a gate agent that knows this then they notionally can legitimately refuse to accept them as valid and require you to pick one or other to determine if you can travel. again very low likelihood, so theoretical risk
australians can enter singapore visa free, could you not solve a lot of the problems by entering and leaving singapore on the australian passport. the details you fill in on the singapore landing card don't have to match what you leave indonesia with (it wont for many dual nationals). that means you never present two passports anywhere.

column5:
at the moment, you simply won't be able to do it. currently you would be likely refused boarding at your point of origin to singapore.
once restrictions go, then you need to have the ability to enter singapore be that a visa in place or be from a visa-free nationality.
other than that, no they won't care remotely. with low cost airlines flying in and out from local regions this is common to transit, or stopover...almost encouraged especially since to enter singapore poof of onward travel is a requirement you need that other ticket.
however, you need to have a routing that doesn't allow through tickets or have pulled a huge deal on the separate flights (eg two lccs) for it to not be worth having a through flight as with disconnected flights you take all risks and losses of non-connects on yourself.
if you purchase online - who from, as some of those ticker floggers are citing prices that simply wont exist any more plus you are putting a third party in between you and any issues that arise. for a package holiday with eu/uk like protections that can be worth it - for flights alone its just someone else charging you money and longer response times normally

column5:
so given you are using singapore as a hub and nothing else, the questions are best asked in the malaysian and indonesian forums.
you will get some answers here as these are likely destinations some posters here will know something about.
so for the acting as a hub thing.
yes singapore is ideal for this to fly into and out to the other countries using either a multicity ticket from your inbound airline (easier if its sia or a codeshare of theirs) or one of several low cost carrier options. that said the lcc network is decent enough to be able to move between malaysia and indonesian locations direct as well. if you make use of lccs make very very sure that your return to singapore for the intercontinental flight gives you plenty of time and spare flight options if things go wrong. at that point they will very probably be separate tickets and a late lcc flight means you burn your return in most cases.
your current plan does exactly what you disliked about your india trip. you wil spend most of the time travelling or in travel related activities (packing, unpacking, transfers, waiting in airports, waiting on checkin times etc). if you want to see these places then you need to narrow things down.
train for singapore to kl - there isnt a direct train anymore. so you have to break things up. there is a decent guide by seat61 here that should be fairly up to date  however note that there are four trains involved - mrt to woodlands, cross border shuttle, one train north and a change to get to kl.
however that does let you stop in penang - one of your listed destinations. so you could use that to get off at butterworth and ferry to penang for one stop (and that includes georgetown obviously). there are however direct flights if you want to see penang more vs the complex journey. penang and ipoh are the two places on your list that would pull me in (though ive only tested penang to see if it met expectation and it did, albeit for a brief stop).
another idea/alteration to throw into consideration. the indonesian island of bintan is a 45minute ferry ride from singapore. decent range of hotels plus the option to see something of the island if you want, but you can also pick the right place and just do 'beach resort' for a few days. much easier and cheaper than many flights.
also and to address the elephant in the room, since this is the singapore forum - why not allocate any time in singapore - although the density and amount the place has to offer you have to make a significant decision on how much time to give.
i think you first need to narrow down the list to get a decent time layout first - then get details from the forums relevant to the destination planned.

column5:
ok so post pandemic we can ignore the current issues.
1) nobody can obtain a transit visa. singapore doesnt operate such a visa. a few indians may qualify for the vftf (visa-free transit facility). that allows 96hr visa free access to singapore, if you are in transit to a third country and have a visa from one of 8 countries (uk, nz, aus, us, canada, japan, switzerland and germany from memory). however, you dont mention anything like that so in that case you require a standard visit visa.
2) the 2.5 hour tour requires you to go through immigration and you have to have entry permission to use it. that tour is basic and you can do better on your own given you have much more time.
3) if your routing requires you to enter singapore (e.g. separate tickets), then the airline staff at your point of origin will check for visas to singapore and only singapore because that is your next point of travel . if your ticketing allows you to transit singapore airside then you don't need a visa for the travel and so they will only check the korean visa. they won't care about the singapore visa.

column4:
visas entry country. limited particular ports entry country trying come care there. visas tied passport person location.
for flight singapore seoul show visa south korea prove right request entry. india singapore leg irrelevant point. leg, return ticket concerns buy separate tickets.
however, flights carefully making separate tickets. buy two return tickets (one india singapore, second singapore south korea) raise number issues.
firstly need multiple entry visa singapore separate tickets guarantee airside transfer return flight set. expected need able pass immigration singapore again. apply singapore visa need include layover travel plans matter brief.
second, cannot normal hours time gap flights return. timings assume single tickets offer protected connections. need leave significantly longer flight allow delays rescheduling similar. arrive singapore south korea separate flight delayed miss neither airline anything you. rebook flight india. possibly recover value original ticket flexibility lose value given ticket t&cs day tendency non-refundable tickets bought.

column5:
visas are for entry to a country. they sometimes are limited to particular ports of entry in the country you are trying to come into but they do not care how you get there. the visas are tied to a passport and a person not a location.
for the flight from singapore to seoul you would show the visa for south korea to prove you have right to request entry. the india to singapore leg is irrelevant at that point. for that first leg, because you have a return ticket then that should be all that concerns them if you buy separate tickets.
however, for these flights do think carefully about making it separate tickets. if you buy two return tickets (one india to singapore, the second singapore to south korea) it raise a number of issues.
firstly you will need a multiple entry visa to singapore as the separate tickets give you no guarantee of airside transfer on the return flight set. you are expected to need and so be able to pass immigration in singapore again. so when you apply for the singapore visa you need to include that layover in the travel plans no matter how brief.
second, you cannot do the normal few hours time gap between flights on the return. those timings assume single tickets which offer protected connections. you need to leave significantly longer between flight to allow for delays and rescheduling and similar. if you arrive in singapore from south korea and have a separate flight out but are delayed so you miss it then neither airline has to do anything for you. you will have to rebook the flight to india. while you can possibly recover some value from the original ticket if it had any flexibility you may lose all value given ticket t&cs these day and the tendency to for non-refundable tickets to be bought.
you can make this one ticket by using a multicity ticket from one airline or airline partner set....so you have one leg india to singapore, stop for two days, then on to south korea but then have the return as a single through journey from korea to india via singapore. that provides you a protected connection on the way home, allowing for a shorter stopover at that point and to remain airside meaning no need to sort a multiple entry visa and fewer problems in the event of delays.
be aware that the online travel bookers who appear to offer the cheap prices mat make this appear cheap by making it separate tickets not a multicity single ticket which could cause yo u problems if you accept their offer without critique

column5:
>>i have just found out today that singapore is on the green list from englanf, i am in discussions with friends of mine as we intend on going there but we have booked a week off in june from june 14th for 7 days<<
sorry but you seem to have fallen into the common misunderstanding about the green list system. it solely represents what uk/england border staff will make you do if you show up from one of the territories or countries on the list. it has no effect on the other places' rules when they are independant countries.
i can almost guarantee that won't be going to singapore in june because they are currently totally closed to people who have been in the uk. there are only about 3 or 4 places they will accept tourists from at the moment. a few more places on preapproved business travel who are kept somewhat in isolation. the rate of change likely means in a month and a halfs time the chances of them having opened to uk origin travellers are negligible i'm sorry to say.
for future reference singapore is easy to get around and tour groups for english speakers are essentially unnecessary. all the regulars here will diy. there are some walking tours that add value from the guide and maybe duck tours and similar. however the core easy to just get hotel and flights and arrive and go yourself.

column5:
i cannot stress this enough, uk pages for entry to singapore are not authoritative for that information. good general information, sure, but not for details and the devil is in the detail here. the comments and description there do not really give a fair reflection on the scope of the changes a couple of weeks ago. the gov.uk page makes it look like anyone can visit short term with permission and thats not a real reflection of reality. if its a change today on the gov/uk website then its running behind when this was changed by singapore near the start of the month.
the singapore ica is the source for this and their page is here

the sole change that has occured recently is that the uk and south africa are now permitted to apply for entry for business and official travel when they were the only two countries excluded. thats not a big change, because we are talking government officials and very very big business - so very small numbers and they are kept in a bubble.
as such, id suggest its not our improving virological profile thats done it. it the fact that the two variants of concern that were first identified in those to countries that led to their exclusion, are now global so there is no reason to exclude the uk and za from that very controlled and restricted business/official box. the requirements there paint a very different picture im afraid.
improvements in our virological profile will only be seen to have an effect once the general traveller is considered by singapore. yes it will happen but not for this change.
edited: 10:36 am, april 21, 2021

column5:
just thought i'd update this thread that i started.
i'm currently in changi airport after my flight from brisbane.
due to flying from australia i am allowed to roam freely thru the terminal, and have found that around 60% of shops and food outlets are open.
as mentioned above, the butterfly garden is closed, but the cactus garden is still open.
for those that smoke, all the smoking areas are still open.
i've seen the monorail system zipping between the terminals but strangely enough when going to the station is says it's not operating at the moment, so i'm either at the wrong station or they are just doing test runs.
the bigger duty free shops are open, but with reduced times, with the cosmetic duty free opening earlier then the alcohol and tobacco duty free shops.
i'm writing this from the krisflyer lounge , after upgrading my singapore to bangkok flight on singapore airways to business class on an bid for upgrade offer. mainly did it for the lounge access as i have an 11hr transit and the bid i put in was actually cheaper then it would have cost for a transit hotel room.

column5:
as dragonlass says - they are illegal to possess in singapore and have been for a few years now. that includes the transit area.. before that change its was importing (ie crossing immigration and entering the country) that was the barrier.
also as noted we have not had a slew of posts stating they had been stopped and lost one whereas you can find quite a few talking about being caught crossing the border. the police arent looking specifically for them in a crackdown and airport security look at items in terms of risk to planes (ie liquids, etc). iirc the post dragonlass refers to the person was using it in the smoking room and got spotted and so possibly not by police.
one that can be broken up so most parts go in checked luggage that transships differently and the battery in hand carry to meet airline rules is the safest way to go. otherwise there is a risk. the past person who email changi and reported back had that phrase used 'there is risk of confiscation' or similar.

column5:
have you chosen an airline to fly in with yet?
if you can use an airline that either flies to tioman or codeshares with one that does then you should be able to pick this up as a through ticket with a stopover or multicity ticket fairly easily and if that airline is sia often cheaply compared to two flights separately or occasionally cheaper than the ticket to singapore alone on the right routing.
i would not have blocks of time in singapore either side of the malaysia stretch myself. that introduces bunches of travel time that could be holiday time and depending upon flight times take 1-2 days out of your schedule. i would either fly through singapore to tioman (or wherever you settle on), and then come back to singapore or arrive in singapore, do the time there then fly to tiomea and then fly back home from tiomen via singapore.
another option is the open jaw ticket where you would use eg ba or a european airline to fly into the malaysian destination and back from singapore with either a cheap lcc carrier from malaysia to singapore or with the right airline a codeshare flight from whoever the intercontinental flights are.
the advantage of through flights is that if things go wrong they are protected connections.
the best option will be determined in part why which malay destination you settle on and who flies there.
your current plan gives you nearly two weeks in singapore which is a really good run at the place.
can i ask what the tioman plan is - as if it is just beach resort there are several alternatives to look at in malaysian islands, plus bintan in indonesia which is just a ferry ride (albeit international) from singapore. bataam also fits that bill though bintan has always attracted me more.

column5:
so your friend travelling to aus - if that was a single ticket then they should have got the boarding pass at poit of origin normally. if they did not i suspect it was to do with australian control of its borders so they would need to confirm they were allowed to fly them and then give them the boarding pass at that point.
the problem with the online checkin suggest by sia is your bags. if you buy scoot as a separate ticket and checkin separately then your bags will get sent to the carousel at changi and you will be expected to get them (ie immigration). no checkin bags and it could work. that limited information is as you say the difference between an hq answer and one from the ops people at the relevant airport. the customer service answer is correct - it just lacks specific local information that is important.
if booking via sia then you can book kuching to london as a single flight - plus with more than one flight per day you do not have to live with the 1hr 50m gap - although that then means a 12hr wait. i just check for the 12th september for example and the 12hr gap is noticeably cheaper (1830myr vs 5800 for the 1hr 50m gap option for economy) although for business that difference disappears as both flight option are 16500myr. so they are selling tickets of this type. it may be the date you want to travel they are full on one leg or the other but the basic possiblity of single through ticket purchase ising scoot from kuching and sia t lhr in business exists and i could run a dummy booking all the way to just before payment n the sept12th date. that was one way (hence the price) - its possible though unlikely that a cheap saver return ticket might be cheaper weirdly.
to be honest ) would investigate the option of an internal flight to kl from kuching and then out to lhr on malaysian. without an immigration barrier to you there the whole flight option becomes so much easier assuming the flights are there.

column5:
no-one here is the singapore government. they make the decisions and they make changes when they are ready. people here con only provide you the current correct information or educated guesses as to the future.
singapore is already open for short term visitors, so long as you are coming from new zealand, australia and a few other places but nowhere else (see list below)
at the current rate of relaxation of controls, for the bulk of other countries (including kuwait that you cite as your location) there is little if any chance for tourist visits. now while that is an informed guess only, because i am not the singapore government - its the best you will get here.
the only get around would be if your visit actually qualifies as essential business travel (which means filling in purpose of visit differently). this is the list of places you can arrive from that would let you do a business visit, if your course fell into that category

currently it doesn't include kuwait but they were media reports about expanding this list in january so you need to watch.
presumably you are not a kuwaiti since you are enquiring about an entry visa and because of that kuwait's embassy functions are operated remotely from singapore. there is no local diplomatic mission according to singapore's ministry of foreign affairs so im guessing you need a visa agent or similar to complete.

personally i would be seeing if the course if still running and will let you cancel given the short time before you need to be there. get some clarity on if you have to start the visa proceedings and presumably book flights etc. and work from there.
i would not expet to be able to do this though.
edited: 9:44 am, january 12, 2021

column4:
pricing strategy origin flights uk based flight through/multicity ticket bkk stopping sin way could well cheaper sin - marketing strategy encourages singapore hub quite common find aviation industry. often much sets tone - looked recently maldives flying maldives £50 cheaper flying singapore seen similar south east asia destinations. could book mutlicity ticket website - using proper brick mortar travel agent plate up.
i wouldnt separate tickets due large amount extra time need add travel cycle transfer safe isnt connection. doesnt bother choice onward airlines. scoot part sia group itself, air asia bangkok hub (not bkk, uses dmk), jetstar run thai airways singapore airlines course. thats normal times, course.
if entire trip fit weeks time off, cut couple days travel out, least disrupted day bkk leg possibly depending upon flight times. thats 11 days holiday time 4-5days bangkok leaves 6-7 singapore isnt huge amount singapore destination (i struggle personal must sees time) lot stopover type visit.
i could fill 14 full days singapore trying hard necessarily hitting major sites - eg wouldt round uss time, i'd need stay weeks universal hit radar. given weeks total maximum decision - trip singapore core, multicentre/couple long stopovers flavour
column5:
if the pricing strategy for us origin flights is the same as for uk based flight them a through/multicity ticket to bkk and stopping in sin on the way back could well be cheaper than one into sin only - its a marketing strategy that encourages use of singapore as a hub and is quite common to find in the aviation industry. often its not by much but still it sets the tone - i looked recently for the maldives and flying through to the maldives was £50 cheaper than flying to singapore itself and i have seen similar for other south east asia destinations. you could book this as a mutlicity ticket on their website - or if you are using a proper brick and mortar travel agent then they will know how to plate it up.
i wouldnt do this as separate tickets due to the large amount of extra time you need to add into the travel cycle to make the transfer safe as it isnt a connection. however if that doesnt bother you then you have a choice on onward airlines. scoot is part of the sia group itself, air asia has a bangkok hub (not at bkk, it uses dmk), jetstar do the run and thai airways and singapore airlines of course. thats all during normal times, of course.
if the entire trip has to fit into 2 weeks of time off, then you have to cut a couple of days for the travel in and out, at least one more disrupted day for the bkk leg and possibly 2 depending upon flight times. so thats down to about 11 days holiday time and 4-5days in bangkok leaves you only 6-7 in singapore which isnt a huge amount for singapore as a destination (i would struggle get through my personal must sees in that time) but its a lot for a stopover type visit.
i could fill 14 full days in singapore without trying too hard and without necessarily hitting all the major sites either - eg i wouldt get round to uss in that time, i'd need to stay 3 weeks for universal to hit my radar. given that if 2 weeks total is the maximum you can take off then you have to make a decision here - is this a trip to singapore at its core, or is it to be a a multicentre/couple of long stopovers in flavour

column4:
remember transiting singapore must ticket ( airline interline/ code share ) boarding pass final destination depart paris. otherwise way return ticket singapore airline, denied boarding paris unless singapore citizen.
the changi airport website list airlines besides singapore airlines transfer with, don’t believe exhaustive. best confirm airline direct.
edited: 2:49 pm, 24,
column5:
remember to be transiting in singapore you must be on one with ticket ( either the same airline or interline/ code share with another ) and already have your boarding pass to your final destination when you depart paris. otherwise what you have is a one way or return ticket to singapore with the first airline, and you will be denied boarding in paris unless you are a singapore citizen.
the changi airport website list other airlines besides singapore airlines that you can transfer with, but i don’t believe it is exhaustive. it is best to confirm with the airline direct.
edited: 2:49 pm, may 24, 2021

barcelona to hong kong with lufthansa, hong kong to manila with cebu air.

column4:
>>how travel agency site (edreams case) flight sell ticket ?<<
dont edreams start. least unless state single ticket assume not.
that agency complained hugely air travel forum. known cobbling together tickets cheaper weay. airlines list interline partnership agreements knowledge - they'll 'one itinerary' isnt 'one ticket' instant accept offer fault meet entry requirements.
anytime itinerary says bags, separate tickets likely. exceptions (eg us, moving london airports etc).
why putting third party online booker flights time all?
column5:
>>how can i know on the travel agency site (edreams in that case) if the flight they sell is on one ticket ?<<
dont use edreams for a start. or at the very least unless they state it is a single through ticket assume it is not.
that agency is complained about hugely on the air travel forum. they are known for cobbling together tickets if its cheaper that weay. the airlines you list above do not have interline or partnership agreements to my knowledge - so they'll give you 'one itinerary' which isnt the same as 'one ticket' and the instant you accept their offer its your fault if you do not meet entry requirements.
anytime an itinerary says to get bags, its separate tickets most likely. there are a few exceptions (eg the us, moving between london airports etc).
why are you putting a third party online booker between you and the flights in this time of all?

column5:
hi all
i've been reading the forum and checking on updates and recommendations. we are hopefully (unless covid cancels) flying to singapore for 3 whole days and 3 nights, and i'm working on itinerary. we've been given copthorne waterfront hotel by my travel company as a hotel - which has good reviews and great location. i love the look of the shangri-la, can afford this but the location doesn't look so favourable. i'm looking at the andaz and also the pan pacific which look better located and within price range. are they all as good as each other or any of them better location than others? thank you

column4:
>> we've given copthorne waterfront hotel travel company hotel - good reviews location<<
its decent location, call due distance mrt lines instance. area isnt wander eat either.
>> love look shangri-la, afford location look favourable.<<
id put copthorne waterfront location, top orchard road fairly easily offers plus botanic gardens walking.
the andaz second best pan pacific best location (imo, obviously).
in terms hotel internal quality - shangrila garden wing somewhat unique. pan pacific hotel tall hollow core construction corridors looking central void lifts made glass - heights issues could big no-no
>>we (unless covid cancels) flying singapore whole days nights,<<
so nights whole days, 3. arrived early morning day travel leave late day departure day impacted degree limits days. right pattern travel add quite lot time quite freedom regular whole day worth thinking separately due possible impingement travel. instance, travel agents try send people night safari day arrival arrived day 'whole day' - practice bad idea due travel.
in part restrictions see days depend exactly flights travel in/out routes destinations/origins are. arriving morning thailand different arriving uk likewise jetting australia evening different issues midday flight vietnam.
a number issues location affected plan - decide taxis speed due maximise whistlestop visit location issue mrt core problem....so there's moderate amount variables pinned could alter comments above.
column5:
>> we've been given copthorne waterfront hotel by my travel company as a hotel - which has good reviews and great location<<
its a decent location, i wouldn't call it great due to distance from mrt lines in the first instance. the area isnt great for wander out and eat either.
>> i love the look of the shangri-la, can afford this but the location doesn't look so favourable.<<
id put it at even with the copthorne waterfront for location, because while being off the top of orchard road you can get down there fairly easily with all that offers plus you have the botanic gardens actually walking.
the andaz is the second best and the pan pacific the best for location (imo, obviously).
in terms of hotel internal quality - the shangrila and its garden wing are somewhat unique. the pan pacific is a great hotel but its a tall hollow core construction with all corridors looking out over that central void and the lifts are made of glass - so for those with heights issues could be a big no-no
>>we are hopefully (unless covid cancels) flying to singapore for 3 whole days and 3 nights,<<
so 3 nights really does mean 2 whole days, not 3. even if you arrived early morning of the day of travel or if you leave late on that day of departure that day will be impacted to some degree or other and there are limits to what you can do on those days. the right pattern of travel can add quite a lot of time but still not quite the freedom of a regular whole day so its worth always thinking of them separately due to possible impingement of travel. for instance, there are some travel agents that still try and send people to the night safari on the day of arrival because they arrived first thing that day and so have a 'whole day' - a practice that is a really bad idea due to the travel.
in part what restrictions you see on those days depend on when exactly the flights or other travel in/out are and what the routes and destinations/origins are. arriving in the morning from thailand is very different to arriving from the uk and likewise jetting out to australia in the evening has different issues to a midday flight out to vietnam.
a number of issues of location can be affected by this and by how you plan to get around - so if you decide taxis for speed due to maximise your whistlestop visit then location issue with mrt may not be a core problem....so there's a moderate amount of variables not pinned down that could alter my comments above.

column4:
taiwan lost control oblige airline pilots strict quarantine. australia, incidents suspected caused way last year, airline staff stay 'red zone' airport, move hotel quarantine, taken airport full ppe next flight within 14 days. can't happen australia.

here's article thailand struggled significantly cases started spread:

that can't happen australia.
at moment, 70 cases across two weeks, victorians can't travel states. that, victoria, approximately 5,000 people considered primary close contacts 14 days quarantine. we're 'third ring' isolation, close contacts 5,000 people quarantine primary close contacts shown mixing infectious period. last heard 5,000 people (because 'released' sooner).
we're lockdown, masks outdoors (even walking alone street), person per day shops (not it).
i suspect many overseas simply understand extremely strict approach here, imagine we're 'surrounded water' assume spreading it.
everyone coming country spends 14 days hotel quarantine tested several times (probably soon include well). vic quarantine staff tested every single day.
as vaccination, yes, uptake slow victoria latest cluster, queues timbuktu vaccination centres, victoria. 42% 50s vic vax. (given 70+ lined reaching time second az, fully vaccinated can't compared countries.)
it's simply possible vaccine far hand picked someone needing hospital treatment someone right tested.
column5:
taiwan lost control because they didn't oblige airline pilots to do strict quarantine. in australia, after a few incidents were suspected of being caused that way last year, airline staff now have to stay in the 'red zone' in the airport, or move into hotel quarantine, and get taken back to the airport with full ppe if their next flight is within 14 days. so that can't happen in australia.

here's an article about how thailand struggled significantly once a few cases started to spread:

that can't happen in australia.
at the moment, for 70 cases across two weeks, victorians can't travel to other states. not only that, in victoria, approximately 5,000 people are considered primary close contacts and are all in 14 days quarantine. as we're doing 'third ring' isolation, the close contacts of those 5,000 people also have to quarantine until their primary close contacts are shown to have not been mixing with them during any infectious period. last i heard that was around another 5,000 people (because they get 'released' sooner).
we're in lockdown, masks outdoors (even if walking alone down the street), and it's one person per day to the shops (not that you'd know it).
i suspect many from overseas simply don't understand the extremely strict approach to it here, and imagine it's because we're 'surrounded by water' and assume that it will get in and be spreading before we know it.
everyone coming in to the country spends 14 days in hotel quarantine and are tested several times (probably soon to include after as well). in vic the quarantine staff are tested every single day.
as for vaccination, yes, uptake was slow until victoria had its latest cluster, now the queues are from here to timbuktu at the vaccination centres, and not just in victoria. 42% of over 50s in vic have had their first vax. (given 70+ who lined up first are only just reaching the time when they can have their second az, fully vaccinated probably can't be compared with other countries.)
it's simply not possible for the vaccine to get too far out of hand before it's picked up by someone needing hospital treatment or someone doing the right thing and being tested.

column4:
>> i’m flying usa thailand layover sin, wondering expect layover changi.<<
ok depends heavily flight tickets bought - flying leg help example. flying - style question sound talking near future rather post-covid.
if separate tickets flying routing covid restrictions lifted permitted enter singapore. however, people seeing cheap flight costs singapore compared tickets grabbing understanding cheap.
post-covid restrictions separate tickets a) need much larger layover transfer safe isnt quick round airport processes b) full round immigration, bag recovery, customs recheckin.
if single journey ticket via singapore checkin currently fine singapore airlines plus limited set agreements with. changi's website sia's website list. stand flight routing plane, moved transit holding area stay next flight. order food drink via app vending machines holding pen otherwise stay there. partial exception layover long enough prebooking transit hotel escorted room escorted stay up. airside transits done much faster currently dont want long help it.
once covid restrictions lifted airside transit simple - plane, disgorged airside sterile departure area, ignore signs immigration/arrival simply anything want time terminal cores want visit, gate opens (1hr 1hr15min ahead takeoff normally).
security changi done gate (hence early opening), full body scanners - 15 across terminals. every gate every flight. different medical devices react different scanning technologies differently, device compatible scanner alternative process. assume travelled likely carry form medical note - show security there. long arent trying dash last minute shouldnt issue.
edited: 3:48 am, july 23,
column5:
>> i’m flying from usa to thailand with a layover at sin, wondering what to expect out of layover at changi.<<
ok so this depends heavily on how the flight tickets are bought - who are you flying with on each leg may help with that for example. also when you are flying - from the style of the question it sound s like we are talking near future rather than post-covid.
if these are separate tickets then you are not flying that routing until covid restrictions are lifted because you are not permitted to enter singapore. however, some people are seeing cheap flight costs in and out of singapore compared to through tickets and grabbing them without understanding why they are cheap.
post-covid restrictions then separate tickets mean a) you need a much larger layover to make the transfer safe and that isnt just about how quick you can get round the airport processes either and b) you do the full round of immigration, bag recovery, customs and then go to recheckin.
if this is a single journey ticket via singapore with through checkin etc then currently that is fine on singapore airlines plus a limited set that they have agreements with. changi's website and sia's website have the list. as things stand for this flight routing you will get off the plane, you then get moved to a transit holding area where you stay until your next flight. you can order food and drink via an app or from vending machines in the holding pen but otherwise you stay there. the partial exception is that if your layover is long enough and you have a prebooking with the transit hotel then you get escorted there and into your room and then escorted back once your stay is up. these airside transits can be done much faster and currently you dont want a long one if you can help it.
once covid restrictions are lifted then an airside transit like this is simple - you get off the plane, you are disgorged into the airside sterile departure area, you ignore signs to immigration/arrival and you simply do anything you want or have time for in the terminal cores you want to visit, you then go to the gate when it opens (1hr to 1hr15min ahead of takeoff normally).
security at changi is done at the gate (hence the early opening), they do have some full body scanners - 15 or so i think across 4 terminals. so its not every gate nor every flight. different medical devices react to different scanning technologies differently, so if your device is not compatible with the scanner they will have an alternative process. i assume since you seem to have travelled before you likely carry some form of medical note for this - just show it to security and they should go from there. so long as you arent trying to dash in last minute it shouldnt be an issue.
edited: 3:48 am, july 23, 2021

column4:

pragnesh - situation improves enough november, tell son enjoyed planned 15-hour layover dubai 2019, overnight layover. took cab gold souk walked part deira, took abra textile souk, walked al fahidi historic area. took cab past sights - including burj khalifa - slept hours pretty hotel heading airport morning flight out. ideally layover entirely daylight hours could see more!, enjoyed small taste dubai. we're looking forward visiting - whenever becomes possible.
column5:
pragnesh, i too am planning a trip to dubai for late november- knowing full well that if the covid situation hasn't improved enough by then, i will cancel my (fully cancel-able) hotel reservations and put our plans on the shelf for another year. shaun, i appreciate your description of the covid regulations currently in place.
pragnesh - if the situation improves enough for you by november, i can tell you that my son and i enjoyed a planned 15-hour layover in dubai in 2019, even though it was an overnight layover. we took a cab to the gold souk and walked around that part of deira, then took an abra over to the textile souk, then walked a bit in al fahidi historic area. we then took a cab past some sights - including the burj khalifa - and slept a few hours at a pretty hotel before heading back to the airport for our morning flight out. ideally our layover would have been entirely in daylight hours so we could see more!, but we enjoyed our small taste of dubai. we're looking forward to visiting again - whenever that becomes possible.

column5:
hi
thought just give an quick update as the forum members have been so kind.
evening flight last night with etihad from lhr, from arriving to the airport to getting through security etc and into duty free took 20mins.
pcr test was checked.
i landed in abu dhabi airport, very quick and efficient and a took a pcr test (took mobile number, but test results arrived within 2 hours on al hosn app).
after taking the pcr test at the airport the airport staff ask how you are booked to get to dubai, i was booked by etihad complimentary chauffeur so they call the service and make sure you are booked onto this, once you exit the terminal they service is waiting for you to transport you.
the whole trip to get to dubai has been quick and found it much quicker than when we were not in covid times.
checked into jw marriott marquis and now just about to jump into the pool
thank you once again

column4:
depends flights ticketed ticketed expedia.
does booking single air canada pnr ticket number (ticket number starts 014-xxxxxxxxxx)? ac responsible rebooking canceled leg. eventually notifying via expedia.
if ticket number starts 157 qatar ticketing airline, 217 thai.
column5:
depends on who the flights were ticketed on and how they were ticketed by expedia.
does your booking have a single air canada pnr and ticket number (ticket number starts 014-xxxxxxxxxx)? if so then ac is responsible for rebooking your canceled leg. and eventually notifying you via expedia.
if the ticket number starts with 157 then qatar is the ticketing airline, or 217 would be thai.

column4: wow realize trip advisor ruthless thai visa. lived 16 years bangkok. wife love phuket rent motorbikes drive place. stayed hilton jan. mar. april got home 29th. missed covid test arrival got hotel received e-mail red white airline return flight cancelled. hire van airport book flight luckily got evening flight bangkok. 1000 baht van. going snorkeling cancelled boat trips bought new go-pro. hilton location staff breakfast unreal. 150 baht person order menu anything want menu get. fresh fruit plate assorted pasties muffins. limit beat that. got email phuket richard claiming stole name clicked register select name id phuket richard 1999 something cares last post life you?
column5: wow i did not realize that this trip advisor was more ruthless than thai visa. first of all i have lived here for 16 years now in bangkok. the wife and i love to go to phuket we rent motorbikes and drive all over the place. we stayed at the hilton in jan. mar. and april just got home on the 29th. just missed the covid test on arrival but when i got to the hotel i received an e-mail from the red and white airline my return flight was cancelled. had to hire a van to go back to the airport to re book the flight luckily got and evening flight to bangkok. 1000 baht for the van. we were going to go snorkeling but that was cancelled no boat trips just bought a new go-pro. now about the hilton it has a great location the staff is great and the breakfast is unreal. 150 baht a person you get to order from the menu anything you want on the menu you can get. fresh fruit plate and assorted pasties and muffins. no limit beat that. i just got an email from phuket richard claiming i stole his name i just clicked to register did not select my name and his id is phuket richard 1999 something who cares this will be my last post get a life will you?

column4: check flight, counter sheet qr codes different districts (krabi, phuket, surat thani) depending airport flying to. scan qr code, register and/or download, prepared show app registration land fill paperwork destination airport. basically want staying, touch sat plane, case need contact tracing.
column5: when you check in for your flight, the counter will have a sheet of qr codes for the different districts (krabi, phuket, surat thani) depending on which airport you are flying to. scan the qr code, register and/or download, be prepared to show the app registration when you land or you will fill out paperwork at the destination airport. they basically want to know where you are staying, how to get in touch and where you sat on the plane, in case they need to do contact tracing.

column4:
booking covid situation thailand certain.
the country almost covid free pandemic started india philippines example new transmissable strains started cause massive escalation numbers could happen here.
the country hopes half population vaccinated year guarantee february quarantine free travel allowed allowed uk (i assume) need spend £1750 uk quarantine hotel.
february high season flights hotels full need rush
as airlines booking phuket vis bangkok sure ticket ticket issued airline delay put next flight self transfer run risk missing onward flight delay.
edited: 4:59 am, april 28,
column5:
i would not booking until the covid situation in thailand is a bit more certain.
the country has been almost covid free since the pandemic started but as in india and the philippines for example where the new more transmissable strains have started to cause a massive escalation in numbers then it could happen here.
the country hopes to have half the population vaccinated this year but there is no guarantee that by february either quarantine free travel will be allowed or you will be allowed back into the uk (i assume) without need to spend £1750 on a uk quarantine hotel.
february isn't high season for flights and the hotels will not be full so no need to rush
as for airlines if booking to phuket vis bangkok make sure the ticket is a through ticket issued by the airline where if there is a delay you will be put on the next flight as if a self transfer you run the risk of missing your onward flight if there is any delay.
edited: 4:59 am, april 28, 2021

column5:
you want to fly manchester-bangkok
how do you plan to get to khao lak ? - its 760 kms from bangkok - thats further than manchester to penzance ?
if you dont mind 14 hours in a coach then go for it but if flying on to phuket first then be aware of the hazards of not booking a through ticket with one airline where if you miss your connection you are stranded and also be aware there re two major airports in bangkok
it may be that searching airlines such as ethiad and emirates who fly from manchester or thai singapore malaysia who all have flights into phuket but would involve leaving from london or tui who run weekly charters are your best bet.
edited: 9:42 am, april 28, 2021

column4:
emirates indeed fly phuket useful (manchester > dubai > phuket) showing bookable website.
other airlines well offer bkk phuket leg part ticket, airline. way luggage transferred change planes bkk airport.
using budget airline last leg cheaper, said above, needs stressed bangkok airports. long haul fly bkk (suvarnabhumi) budget airlines fly mueang (dmk). 40 minute bus ride two, plus check in. recommended long haul flight unless used it.
column5:
emirates did indeed fly into phuket which would be useful (manchester > dubai > phuket) and are showing it as bookable on their website.
other airlines may well offer the bkk to phuket leg as part of a through ticket, even though it is with another airline. doing it this way your luggage is transferred for you and you just change planes in bkk airport.
using a budget airline for the last leg is cheaper, but as said above, it needs to be stressed that bangkok has 2 airports. most long haul fly into bkk (suvarnabhumi) and most budget airlines fly out of don mueang (dmk). it is a 40 minute bus ride between the two, plus another check in. not recommended after a long haul flight unless you are used to it.

column4:
pebbles - la vela much location. going february 22, 'adults only' aspect weigh heavily, lot families.
simonpedal - "most budget airlines fly mueang (dmk)", true anymore. thai vietjet, thai smile airasia flights leave suvarnabhumi days. thai lion, nok rest airasia flights leave mueang. travelers making connections need pay attention airports book flights via.
column5:
pebbles - la vela is a much better location. but if you are going in february 22, i don't think the 'adults only' aspect will weigh too heavily, as there will probably not be a lot of families.
simonpedal - "most budget airlines fly out of don mueang (dmk)", that is not so true anymore. thai vietjet, thai smile and some airasia flights leave from suvarnabhumi these days. thai lion, nok and the rest of airasia flights leave from don mueang. but travelers making connections do need to pay attention to which airports they book flights via.

column4:
"technically illegal kind work work permit paying taxes."
true, thai laws updated reflect digital era. practically speaking issue working remotely thailand. fact government actively exploring possibility promoting thailand destination digital nomads. regarding taxes, thai ip address one's income subject thai income tax (and yes tax professional).
column5:
"technically it is illegal to do any kind of work without a work permit and paying taxes."
true, but only because thai laws have not been updated to reflect the digital era. practically speaking there is no issue working remotely in thailand. in fact the government has been actively exploring the possibility of promoting thailand as a destination for digital nomads. regarding taxes, just having a thai ip address does not make one's income subject to thai income tax (and yes i am a tax professional).
