column4:
70s simply standard on-loan elder octopus card.

this access cheap fares - hk$2 bus, ferry mtr journeys. hand airport customer service desk way deposit remaining credit (less small handling fee). buy cards machine airport using credit card, refund end hk$ cash, guess coffee onward flight something.
you plenty time lantau/buddha/tai trip bus almost cost. flights airline bags checked boarding passes onward flight need airport 45-60 minutes flight,
edited: 8:23 am, 03,
column5:
if you are in your 70s you should simply each get an standard on-loan elder octopus card.

this will give you access to very cheap fares - hk$2 for most bus, ferry and mtr journeys. you can hand it back at the airport customer service desk on your way out and get your deposit and any remaining credit back (less a small handling fee). you can buy the cards from a machine at the airport using a credit card, but the refund at the end will be in hk$ cash, which i guess you can use on a coffee before your onward flight or something.
you should have plenty of time to do the lantau/buddha/tai o trip by bus for almost no cost. if your flights are on the same airline then all your bags and stuff will be checked through and you will have your boarding passes for the onward flight so you only need to get back to the airport 45-60 minutes before your flight,
edited: 8:23 am, may 03, 2021

column4:
** suggestions based situation covid **
half day trip macau unrealistic - total round trip traffic 3-4 hours already. full day feasible.
also, consider flying macau singapore / bangkok, stay night two macau early hmz bus hong kong morning flight. logistic easier. comment south east asia part familiar there.
or taking eva air following merits
- open jaw ticket allows arriving hong kong leaving yyz macau (both transit taiwan)
- free stopover taiwan (depends fare rules), yyz- tpe transit - hkg + macau - khh (make way tpe) tpe - yyz week so
anyway, international travel normalized 2022.
edited: 11:54 am, february 28,
column5:
** any suggestions below are based on the situation that is without the covid **
half day trip in macau is just unrealistic - the total round trip traffic itself can take you 3-4 hours already. a full day is more feasible.
also, you may consider flying to macau from singapore / bangkok, stay a night or two in macau and take the early hmz bus to hong kong for the morning flight. that should make the logistic easier. no comment on the south east asia part as not familiar with there.
or you may also think of taking eva air with the following merits
- you can have open jaw ticket that allows you arriving at hong kong and leaving to yyz from macau (both with one transit in taiwan)
- free stopover at taiwan (depends on the fare rules), say yyz- tpe transit - hkg + macau - khh (make your way to tpe) tpe - yyz for a week or so
anyway, i myself do not think that international travel can be normalized even in 2022.
edited: 11:54 am, february 28, 2021
column8: Advice on a trip to Asia

column4: prefer fly 2.30am makes time dubai giving last full day. usually 4pm check leave bags hotel sight seeing/shopping, followed nice dinner head hotel collect bags, quick change cloths, airport sleep flight.

column5:
i am seeking advice about what to do about a ticket that i can't get refunded or rebooked, wonder if anyone has had similar problems. i bought a ticket from cheapoair from taiwan to japan haneda with 16 hr layover then transfer to narita and then on to the us, when i got to the gate they told me i could not stay at narita overnight as i planned and that since i was transiting in japan i could not board without showing that i had booked a quartine approved hotel and transportation. they didn't have a list of such hotels, in the time that i was trying to get cheapo to book one for me the gate closed and i missed the flight. there was no way i could have known about this problem before i got into the airport, cheapoair had sent a generic email telling customers that they responsible for knowing covid regulations in the countries that they travel in, on the japan airlines website it lists the entry restrictions as:
travelers who are not entering japan and transferring directly to a third country by transit, are not required to submit any documents and undergo pcr tests.
however, the following cases require entry into japan. please be informed that foreign nationals arriving from prohibited countries will not be allowed to enter japan.
- transferring between tokyo international airport (haneda airport) and narita international airport
- travelers with a connecting flight out of narita international airport the following day
i am not entering from a prohibited country and have a negative prc test so i thought i was ok. it says nothing about a quarantine hotel or narita being closed overnight. both airports also do not mention it.
cheapoair says japan airlines marked me as a no show and i can't rebook or get a refund and that i should contact japan airlines, japan airlines says that i was marked as a no-show at the gate and can't rebook me, they tell me to contact cheapoair for a refund.
i can't possibly see how i could have known about this requirement and been in compliance with the rule. it's completely unfair. i feel like cheapoair is more responsible because they are a travel agency and the reason people use them is so that they won't have problems like this, they should have informed me of the rule and they still today are selling flights that connect from haneda to narita right now that their customers will buy but cannot use. japan airlines also should have this information on their website and also should not have listed me as a no-show. i'm extremely unhappy with both of them and very angry that they both pass off the responsibility to each other.

i hesitant plans fall, reservations cancelled penalty; pain cancelling trip japan distressing.
column5:
i'm feeling optimistic about the effectiveness of the vaccines, but i understand why japan would be hesitant to let americans visit. given how many americans ignore local rules around mask-wearing, why should they trust us not to forge our vaccination cards? hotels and other travel-related businesses in japan must be hurting, so there will be pressure to come up with a system that allows foreign tourists without putting japanese people at risk.
i am hesitant to make any plans for the fall, even reservations that can be cancelled without penalty; the pain of cancelling a trip to japan would be too distressing.

i believe herbal remedies, i've excellent results ginger capsules prevent motion sickness. they're corrosive, important plenty water.
osaka, kobe, kyoto part metropolitan area (kansai), could stay city (preferably kyoto) visit others day trips changing hotels. hotel stay cities save inconvenience switching hotels, flexibility schedule.
column5:
if it doesn't cost too much more, consider flying to tokyo and returning home from osaka. that could save you some travel time at the end of your trip.
i don't believe in herbal remedies, but i've actually had excellent results from ginger capsules to prevent motion sickness. they're a bit corrosive, so it's important to take them with plenty of water.
osaka, kobe, and kyoto are all part of the same metropolitan area (kansai), so you could stay in one city (preferably kyoto) and visit the others as day trips without changing hotels. having one hotel stay for all these cities will save you the inconvenience of switching hotels, and will also give you more flexibility with your schedule.

column5:
all but one of my 6 trips to japan have been solo. one 5 1/2 week trip was solo for two of the weeks, the rest with my husband.
it is much easier to navigate japan than you would think as the signs and leader boards in the railway and bus stations are in english as well as japanese and the street signs in many places have both languages
.spoken english may be more limited. japanese children are taught english in school but spoken english is not part of the exams (i was told by a japanese teacher of english) and the students are focussed on what they need for exams.
whether you enjoy solo travel is more a question of your own personality than of your destination.
i'm not quite sure what you mean by "working at the same time".
if you mean working remotely at your regular job, be aware that fast broadband isn't as ubiquitous as you might think, so check before you book hotels. i have certainly received work emails when i travel and have had to, at times stay inside and work for a 1/2 day or day at a time but it has not been part of a plan.
if you mean pick up work in japan as you go, you would need a different sort of visa from the usual tourist visa and, i suspect, have certain not generally available skills.
don't count on working illegally.
it is never really safe, but in such an orderly and generally law abiding country it strikes me as even more unwise than usual,

column4: independent worker base anywhere, pandemic restrictions over, enter japan casual visitor work remotely. engaging japanese companies receiving compensation stay, need working visa. course, cannot overstay visitor visa limits.
column5: if you are an independent worker who can base out of anywhere, then once the pandemic restrictions are over, you can enter japan as a casual visitor and just work remotely. since you are not engaging with any japanese companies or receiving compensation from them during your stay, you should not need a working visa. of course, you cannot overstay your visitor visa limits.

column4:
op, issues encountered discussed many times forum. visited forum book ticket, read beyond official channel.
i channel possible refund cheapo, chance giving anything slim. responsible ever changing rules difficult covid time. cheapo noted website book. hurt though, long shot.
jal likely refund. thing, customer. cheapo paid seat, wasted show up. jal fly flight.
it widely discussed worst choice online agent book airline ticket. disadvantages using third party reseller became clear covid time airlines cancelled flights, countries establish travel bans, etc. need visit travel forum read them.
it unfortunate likely lose money.
column5:
op, the issues you encountered have been discussed many times in this forum. had you visited this forum before you book your ticket, you would have read about them beyond the other official channel.
i also think your only channel of a possible refund is from cheapo, but the chance of them giving you anything is very slim. because you are the one who is responsible to know all the ever changing rules during this difficult covid time. and cheapo already noted that on their website when you book. it does not hurt to ask though, it may be a long shot.
jal would likely not give you a refund. for one thing, you are not their customer. cheapo is the one who paid them for a seat, which was wasted because you did not show up. jal did fly that flight.
it is widely discussed that it is the worst choice to use an online agent to book an airline ticket. all the disadvantages of using a third party reseller became very clear during the covid time when airlines cancelled flights, countries establish travel bans, etc. you just need to visit any travel forum to read about them.
it is unfortunate that you will likely lose money.

column5:
thanks for that!
i completely understand and i know that i am on the outer edge of optimism in moving forward with planning! maybe i'm suffering from "vaccination fever" (my second shot is next week...) and can't stop myself from planning to getaway!
that said, so much is changing so fast, in every possible direction, i wanted to have things in place in case things improve for all of us. and the flexibility of many of the services (accommodation, flights) make it a little easier to extend myself since they are either refundable and/or i can convert to open tickets (as i did last year...).
that said, i'm supposed to come for a project that is decidedly site-specific. my hope is to try and include some educational travel at the same time, with the caveat that i need to be aware i might be in quarantine or not allowed to come at all.
thanks again for that! i will keep an eye out and fingers crossed for all of us things really turn the corner soon!

column4:
seems policy brought show something done, rather try set effective way stop variant covid cases getting country.
firstly given good two weeks notice majority people planning come red list country could new rule brought - last week long queues people airports that.
secondly set airports england - lhr, lgw, lcy bhx, plus farnborough private jets. planning fly man lba example meant change flights others, thereby leaving miles want hotel stay ends well costing more.
thirdly seems foolproof process stop people getting round it, given flying ion flights non red list countries.
fourthly, surely dangerous let people red list countries uk quarantine hotel, safe let people share plane others many hours?
i see turkish airlines flight edi gla (scotland quarantining everyone lands there) came grand total passengers today. 60 booked decided fly realised quarantined. wonder many transferred flights england instead?
column5:
it seems to me that this policy has just been brought in to show that something is being done, rather than to try to set up an effective way to stop variant covid cases getting in to the country.
firstly we have given a good two weeks notice so that the majority of people planning to come in from a red list country could get here before the new rule was brought in - last week there were long queues of people at airports doing just that.
secondly it's only been set up at 4 airports in england - lhr, lgw, lcy and bhx, plus farnborough for all those private jets. if you were planning to fly into man or lba for example you were meant to change your flights to one of the others, thereby leaving you miles from where you want to be when your hotel stay ends as well as costing you even more.
thirdly there seems to be no foolproof process to stop people getting round it, given they are all flying ion on flights from non red list countries.
fourthly, surely if it's dangerous to let people from red list countries into the uk without quarantine in a hotel, how is it safe to let the same people share a plane with others for however many hours?
i see that a turkish airlines flight into either edi or gla (scotland quarantining everyone that lands there) came in with a grand total of 5 passengers today. there were a further 60 booked who decided not to fly when they realised they would be quarantined. i wonder how many transferred to flights into england instead?

column5:
your plan of an overnight stop is a good one. if you can leave earlier on the saturday morning you might miss some traffic, but that’s debatable.
all i can suggest is you prepare for a lot of delays, have water and snacks with you and just accept it’s going to take a long time.
flying into newquay would also work, but then you have to get to your accommodation from the airport (and back again) which would realistically mean taxis. and although you can cycle and walk places, it’s always good to have the car just in case you want to go somewhere further afield.
you seem to be coming with the right attitude, i hope you enjoy your break

i uk resident wife (she belgian resident) means allowed lhr's immigration control per current regulation. therefore, transiting airside going immigration viable option. carry hand luggage check brussels flight online beforehand makes *in principle* proceed directly connecting flight going immigration.
but worries this:

column5:
hello. i'm turning to the tripadvisor community after an excruciating experience of trying to clarify this with ba and heathrow - perhaps someone here has first-hand insights.
my main question is whether it is feasible to fly back from a red list country to brussels transiting via lhr with two separate bookings. there are some more relevant details which i write down below.
me and and my wife are flying back from mexico city (which is on the red list) to brussels via lhr. both flights are with ba but they are two separate tickets due to to the fact that our outbound flight is from lhr. e.g., lhr-mexico city return trip is one ticket, and lhr-brussels is a separate add-on ticket. the flight to brussels leaves 4hrs after scheduled arrival at lhr, i.e. it is same-day transit.
i am a uk resident while my wife is not (she is a belgian resident) which means she would not be allowed through lhr's immigration control as per current regulation. therefore, transiting airside without going through immigration is our only viable option. we only carry hand luggage and would check in for the brussels flight online beforehand which makes me think that *in principle* we are ok to proceed directly to the connecting flight without going through immigration.
but what worries us is this:
1) mexico city-lhr-brussels trip is two separate tickets: we are worried that the check-in staff in the mexico city airport would take into consideration the mexico city-lhr flight in isolation which means pre-booking quarantine hotel for me and a denied boarding for my wife (as she is a non-resident). this would seem absurd to me especially given that both flights are with ba but i am simply not able to confirm this with anyone.
2) say, we are not able to check-in online for the lhr-brussels flight beforehand which means we would not have a proper transit proof to show before boarding the mexico city-lhr flight. and even if we are somehow able to board that flight, we would anyway need to go through immigration at lhr to do a check-in for the lhr-brussels flight.
i see now this has become a lengthy post but we are rather desperate so any advice would be much appreciated.
column8: Transit from red list country through UK: 2 separate tickets

column5:

we will be returning to canada sept 16. flying from krakow (krakow to glasgow to gatwick) on sept 15, and had planned on spending the night in the airport before flying home the next morning. we are both canadian citizens, fully vaccinated, and will be completing a pcr test before leaving krakow. i am aware that canada is currently on the amber list.
i made a booking in june to stay at the bloc gatwick, thinking that since it’s in the terminal we would not be considered as leaving the airport and ok for covid restrictions. this morning i received an email from bloc offering a discount for their “reopening” sept 22. it appears that even though they are closed, they took the reservation and accepted my payment, but that sort of thing has been par for the course with this trip!
so here’s my question: is it possible to stay in a hotel near the airport given current restrictions, or are we doomed to trying to get comfy ion a seat in the terminal for the night? i know being on the amber list we have to quarantine, take day 2 test, etc., but would appreciate any enlightenment for this type of situation where you are transiting with an overnight stay.
thank you in advance for any help!

column4:
i’ll upset few, given changes etc. reckon driving door door (depending edinburgh last door is) could well fastest.
if leave early enough you’ve got drive south dover, rest easy relentlessly dull long drive. leaving 6am train obvious solution.
i’ve tried flying, major airports (lgw stn) work slower account check / security times well access airports. lcy much services suit it’s hardly easiest place north east kent.
clearly train potential, you’ve got station arrive edinburgh you’ve got onward journey. looking saving 90 minutes actual travelling time going train, eroded changes onward connections. experience leaving early could drive, stop three times edinburgh waverley park time pick friend used public transport set later. added grief lugging luggage - mind working train.
column5:
i’ll upset a few, but given the changes etc. i reckon driving door to door (depending on where in edinburgh the last door is) could well be fastest.
if you leave early enough then although you’ve got to drive south to dover, the rest is just an easy but relentlessly dull long drive. leaving after 6am and train is the obvious solution.
i’ve tried flying, the major airports (lgw and stn) work out slower when you take into account the check in / security times as well as the access to and from the airports. lcy is much better but services may not suit you and it’s hardly the easiest place to get to from north east kent.
clearly the train has most potential, but you’ve got to get to the station and when you arrive in edinburgh you’ve got an onward journey. you are probably looking at saving 90 minutes actual travelling time going by train, which will be eroded by changes and onward connections. my experience leaving early was that i could drive, stop three times and get to edinburgh waverley and park in time to pick up a friend who had used public transport and set off later. and he had the added grief of lugging his luggage about too - mind you he was working on the train.

column4:
'flight lands 9am, easy jet departs 11:00am. enough time?' impossible whether sufficient time.
whether westjet air transat yyz-lgw, chances carrier change timetable may/will delays day toronto gatwick. willing risk losing easyjet tickets two hours enough time, risk chance able stay airside. way determine passport control travel.
i want least five six hours flights separate tickets, depending travel canada uk develops next three months add overnight stay gatwick, need gauge risk tolerance.
column5:
'flight lands at 9am, easy jet departs at 11:00am. is that enough time?' it's impossible to say whether this will be sufficient time.
whether westjet or air transat from yyz-lgw, there are chances that the carrier may change the timetable or that there may/will be delays on the day out of toronto or into gatwick. if you're willing to risk losing the easyjet tickets then two hours may be enough time, but it's a risk i would not take even if there is a chance you would be able to stay airside. there is no way to determine what passport control may be like when you travel.
i would want at least five or six hours between flights with separate tickets, and depending on how travel between canada and the uk develops over the next three months i might add an overnight stay at gatwick, but you need to gauge your own risk tolerance.

column5:
i think the economics of maintaining wired ethernet mean it’s the dodo of hotel networking. putting an access point in a corridor is a lot cheaper than running cables to each room, terminating both ends and having a room full of wires and a patch panel hidden away somewhere.
maybe a business centre might have wired connections, but the op isn’t clear if this is a business trip or leisure with an internet need (10mb could mean anything, but it’s not anything special by my reckoning).

column5:
hello,
i got the flight deal for $225 to hnd from dallas, arriving early morning on monday 11/22 and departing mid-morning on wednesday 12/1.
i’d never really seriously considered a trip to japan before because the combo of the expensive flights + reputation as an expensive destination deterred me, but the price was too good to turn down.
there is (hopefully) going to be a sumo tournament in fukuoka while i’m there, so my initial thought was to fly to fukuoka to start and then work my way back north by train/bus.
what should i do? i’m into history and culture, natural beauty, but open to pretty much anything. would like to do a day at universal studios for nintendo+potter world. so that + the sumo are 2 days, and i basically have 7-8 more days to fill. what do i do?
i am a budget traveler so would love hostel or japanese-style guesthouse recs and cheap delicious eats suggestions. i could probably splurge on a nice dinner or two ($50-$100 per person range). i tend to save my money to spend on experiences so any tour suggestions or cool places i would love to hear.
the flights are flexible, and let’s assume that vaccinated travelers are allowed into japan without quarantine (i know that may end up not being the case), and that japan is in the new normal before the most recent lockdown coming up.
would love any itinerary suggestions!
edited: 5:11 pm, april 23, 2021

column4:
full value ticket towards something change penalty sure travel airline (aa?), minimal risk japan open up. boat you, expect much expensive ticket july. announced olympics allow foreigners in, knew trouble. thankfully schedule change enabled refund.
what japan course depends tastes long there. sure hotels penalty cancellation. want tokyo planning making extensive transportation system, japan rail pass worth looking to. sure purchase close date travel look way.
hope works out. so, found rare inexpensive way there. not, least place ticket value.
column5:
if you can use the full value of the ticket towards something else without a change penalty and you know you for sure will travel with the airline (aa?), then there is minimal risk if japan does not open up. i was in the same boat as you, expect a much more expensive ticket in july. when they announced the olympics would not allow foreigners in, i knew i was in trouble. thankfully a schedule change enabled the refund.
what to do in japan of course depends on your tastes and how long you are there. make sure all of your hotels have no penalty for cancellation. if you want to get out of tokyo and are planning on making extensive use of the transportation system, a japan rail pass might be worth looking in to. just be sure not to purchase it until very close to the date of travel if things look like they will go your way.
hope it works out. if so, you found a rare inexpensive way to get there. if not, at least there will be another place to use the ticket value.
column8: Got a cheap flight—no clue what to do

column4:

column5:
thanks for the info on the sumo ticket sale dates.
i suppose it depends on a country's stance on whether vaccinated travelers are a risk and how much business/tourist trade is important to them. greece is already reopening to vaccinated americans, though obviously they are culturally different, more economically hard up, and more dependant on tourism than japan. mexico never closed to american tourists, even before vaccination, and doesn't even require a negative test result to enter.
i am hopeful but not optimistic that with 7 additional months of vaccinations that japan will be willing to admit vaccinated travelers. sumo tickets will probably be the only thing i would purchase without confirmation that the border is in fact open to me, but it was too good of a flight deal to turn down considering i paid $225 for flights from texas and that the fare is flexible if i can't go to japan.
i would think, especially with reduced crowd sizes, it will probably be possible to resell the sumo tickets if it turns out i can't come.

column4:
specific interest himeji beyond castle? himeji castle normally requires roughly 2.5 hours max. add koko-en (garden) next door, allow extra hour. decide visit mt. shosha, himeji becomes full day trip. kobe easily visited day trip kyoto osaka well unless plan stay overnight arima onsen. hand, focus himeji castle plus parts kobe, combine two day trip.
your itinerary otherwise impossible fit within days. assume extra days after? that's case, need include kyoto osaka within pass window transport cost within cities minimal. also, jr trains much coverage casual visitor places.
let's days:
1-4 kyoto overnight
4 nara 1/2 day trip, kyoto afternoon
5 mid morning train kinosaki onsen (get lunch), overnight kinosaki
6 kinosaki onsen osaka overnight
7 himeji + kobe day trip, overnight osaka
8 osaka fly out
in case, maximize pass value active day day 8, covering various trips plus haruka express ride kix airport.
column5:
do you have some specific interest in himeji beyond the castle? himeji castle normally requires roughly 2 to 2.5 hours max. even if you add koko-en (garden) next door, allow an extra hour. if you decide to visit mt. shosha, then himeji becomes a full day trip. kobe can easily be visited as a day trip from kyoto or osaka as well unless you plan to stay overnight at arima onsen. on the other hand, if you focus on himeji castle plus just parts of kobe, you can combine the two into a day trip.
your itinerary is otherwise impossible to fit within 5 days. i assume you have some extra days before or after? if that's the case, you won't need to include kyoto or osaka within the pass window since transport cost within these cities are minimal. also, jr trains don't have much coverage for the casual visitor at these places.
let's say you have 8 days:
1-4 kyoto overnight
4 nara 1/2 day trip, back to kyoto in the afternoon
5 mid morning train to kinosaki onsen (get there for lunch), overnight kinosaki
6 kinosaki onsen back to osaka overnight
7 himeji + kobe day trip, overnight osaka
8 osaka to fly out
in the above case, you can maximize pass value by having it active from day 4 to day 8, covering your various trips plus a haruka express ride back to the kix airport.
column8: Planning a 16 days trip in Kansai

column4:
indeed, flying tokyo flying osaka visit hiroshima planned, plan suggested dli (singel ticket tokyo - kyoto, kansai hiroshima pass kyoto/osaka - hiroshima - kyoto/osaka) economical jr pass.
the caveat kansai hiroshima pass cannot shinkansen kyoto osaka. limited express train (recommended) local trains shin-osaka first. big deal sort experience uk european train transfers.
column5:
indeed, if you are flying into tokyo and flying out of osaka with a visit to hiroshima planned, the plan suggested by dli (singel ticket tokyo - kyoto, kansai hiroshima pass kyoto/osaka - hiroshima - kyoto/osaka) is more economical than the jr pass.
the only caveat with the kansai hiroshima pass is you cannot use shinkansen between kyoto and osaka. you will have to use a limited express train (recommended) or other local trains to shin-osaka first. it's not a big deal though if you have any sort of experience with uk or european train transfers.
column8: Green Car Japan rail - or just Rail Pass?

column4:
want save time money, 10-night trip tokyo kyoto/osaka included, look open jaw flights (fly tokyo, fly osaka vice versa). could sense transit tokyo to/from osaka. train way tokyo osaka. days, open jaw flights normally cost much, flying into/out airport.
for example, fly tokyo, visit city, shinkansen kyoto, visit kyoto/osaka, fly osaka (via tokyo necessary) home.
column5:
if you want to save time and money, for a 10-night trip with tokyo and kyoto/osaka included, look into open jaw flights (fly into tokyo, fly out of osaka or vice versa). it could make sense even if you have to transit through tokyo to/from osaka. you then just take the train one way between tokyo and osaka. these days, open jaw flights normally don't cost much, if any more than flying into/out of the same airport.
for example, you can fly into tokyo, visit the city, take shinkansen to kyoto, visit kyoto/osaka, and the fly out of osaka (via tokyo if necessary) to get home.

column4: global715255 raises important point. japan fully opens foreign tourists fall 2021, new variants coronavirus begin circulating, japan shut again, leaving airport transfer haneda narita allowed public transportation. plane tickets fully refundable, buy new tickets then-prevailing prices.
column5: global715255 raises an important point. even if japan fully opens to foreign tourists in fall 2021, new variants of the coronavirus might begin circulating, and japan might shut down again, leaving you with an airport transfer between haneda and narita that you won't be allowed to do on public transportation. even if your plane tickets are fully refundable, you might have to buy new tickets at the then-prevailing prices.

column4:
clarify, two pnr's (one airline). important whether two flights going ticket? not, emirates responsible miss onward flight.
for reasons mentioned above, best book day transfer flights using two separate airports. fact, book journey normal times.
column5:
to clarify, you will have two pnr's (one from each airline). the important thing is whether two flights are going to be on the same ticket? if not, emirates won't be responsible if you miss the onward flight.
for all the other reasons mentioned above, it's best not to book same day transfer flights using two separate airports. in fact, i wouldn't even book this journey during normal times.

column4:

column5:
i would fly this route. it will be faster and also, likely cheaper. you can always take shinkansen at some other point of your trip--perhaps as a day trip from tokyo.
fukuoka airport serves some international destinations but you won't find a direct flight to the us. you will have to transit somewhere. if you are going to connect at tokyo or osaka on the same day, make sure you choose the same airport for both flights.

column4:
14-day jr pass payoff long return tokyo expires, itin above. maximize benefits, activate d5 travel nikko. round trip jr shinkansen + local train costs jpy10k+ per adult.
the jr green car fact provides less flexibility seats reserved, there's car per shinkansen. green car usually taken local business travels thus quite full.
given frequent shinkansen service (during normalcy), reserve normal seats day before. need change last minute, jr ticket office charge.
in japan, luggage delivery service send luggage day advance.
column5:
the 14-day jr pass would more than payoff as long as you return to tokyo before it expires, re the itin above. to maximize its benefits, activate it on d5 to travel to nikko. a round trip by jr shinkansen + local train costs jpy10k+ per adult.
the jr green car in fact provides less flexibility as all seats have to be reserved, and there's only 1 car per shinkansen. the green car is usually taken up by local business travels and thus can be quite full.
given frequent shinkansen service (during normalcy), just reserve normal seats the day before. should you need to change at last minute, just go to jr ticket office for such with no charge.
in japan, use the luggage delivery service to send luggage 1 day in advance.

column5:
2nd april, flight to hue for the hue festival, stay two nights.
==> let's say you stay the nights of ap 2-3 in huế; then on the very early morning of apr 4, take the se8 train to ninh bình.
at the moment, the only train showing is the se8; i don't know if they will resume any of the other trains by then. the departure of the se 8 is at 3h12 (in the wee hours of the morning), arriving at 16h07.
can you deal with that?
otherwise, consider paying for a longer train trip (đà nẵng - hà nội):
- the se 6 schedule: 10h35 (đn) - 4h35 (hn) the next day.
but you will get on in huế at about 13h37 in the early afternoon and jump off at ninh bình around 3h (in the wee hours of the morning the next day).
- the se 4 schedule: 12h56 (dn) - 5:50 (hn) the next day
but you will get on in huế at about 16h in the afternoon and jump off at ninh bình around 4h20 (next day morning, which apr 5.
the train schedule may very well change in the future as i think i already saw some discrepancy between the info on the official website (dsvn.vn) and those of the resellers or information providers (like the man in seat 61)
in another word, you need to consider the downtime on a long stretch and give yourself enough time.
otherwise, you may have to fly into hanoi and start the northern portion of the trip there.
john
edited: 9:20 am, march 04, 2021

column5:
i did a lot of looking just before the lockdown as i wanted to get from phu quoc to bangkok.
i reckon the easiest and quickest for you is bangkok air to bangkok and then with them to phuket. however this probably won't be cheapest.
cheaper are probably budget airlines, but to do this you will have to go to saigon > bangkok > phuket.
airasia via kl is probably nearly as easy, but may be more expensive because you do 2 'international' flights (internals are normally cheaper).
a couple of things to remember
only flight from phu quoc to bangkok is bangkok air. this is a turbo prop so not so fast or comfortable.
bangkok air fly to suvarnabhumi airport. almost all thai budget airlines fly from don muang - a 1 hr (free) bus ride away.
nb just before lockdown airasia said they were going to have a few flights from suvarnabhumi. not which ones.

love saigon often spend couple weeks context 4-6 months travelling asia. month play with, days right. perhaps little bangkok. easy spread time thinly asia but, imo going far way. live cities fair enough, (though couldn’t pay spend amount time pattaya!)
as flying getting region, fruitless exercise trying source airfare determine routes current climate. anything booked anytime soon likely subject change cancellation. cheapest way likely fly bkk find regional flights budget carriers. variety reasons preferred option air asia many carriers sea. flexibilty , issue you, so, booking way advance yield cheap fares, needed pay additional flexibility.

column5:
i love saigon and often spend a couple of weeks there but in the context of maybe 4-6 months travelling in asia. with a month to play with, 3 days would be about right. perhaps a little more for bangkok. it is very easy to spread your time too thinly in asia but, imo you are going too far the other way. if you live cities fair enough, (though you couldn’t pay me to spend that amount of time in pattaya!)
as for flying to and getting around the region, it can be a fruitless exercise trying to source airfare and determine routes in the current climate. anything booked anytime soon is likely to be subject to change or cancellation. the cheapest way is likely to be to fly into bkk and then find regional flights with budget carriers. for a variety of reasons my preferred option is air asia but there are many other carriers in sea. flexibilty , may not be an issue for you, if so, booking way in advance can yield really cheap fares, though if needed you can pay for additional flexibility.
the most time effective method, as suggested above, is to go for an open jaw ticket, say into bkk and our from sgn .
the only time i have found booking all the fare together on the same ticket is where there are special sales on or where flying from u.k. to australia stopping over in sea for a while along the way.
we have stayed all over saigon over the years, from five star places to small budget places. six or seven years ago we found ms yangs homestay in district 3 and wouldn’t stay anywhere else. though in d3 it is walking distance to the war remnants museum and the reunification palace and is in a non touristy neighbourhood with some really great places to eat.
given your sated interest in the war, i would seriously consider a few days in saigon before travelling through the mekong delta and getting a boat to phnom penh, another wonderful city. aging , as suggested above, maybe hit angkor from there or head off to bangkok.

leave halong bay 12 midday, bus / car hanoi, airport flight bangkok, taking consideration time need check international flight.

column5:
"want to visit hanoi for 1 night, ha long bay for 2 nights, 1 night in bangkok and then 4 nights in phuket?"
ok, so at best, you arrive in hanoi early morning.
clear customs and immigration, hour drive into the city, check in, unpack, out on the street to look around, hopefully, by lunch time.
all the while dealing with jetlag / possible long and tiring travelling time / possible heat.
early night, pick around 8am the next morning to go to halong bay; two nights there.
leave halong bay around 12 midday, bus / car back through hanoi, and then out to the airport for a flight to bangkok, taking into consideration the time you need to check in for an international flight.
arrive bangkok around.....??? it'll be rather late.
which doesn't give you much time for your one night there.
up the next day, and off to phuket.
"is that doable...."
i guess it is. but would you really want to?
".....or are there any other recommendations."
yep, pick one country.
scott

column4:
hello nigel,
vân đồn international airport, number routes limited served chartered flights; last saw regular flight shenzhen, china.
from đà nẵng, fly hanoi (nội bài airport - han) hải phòng (cát bi airport - hph).
hải phòng international airport, connect shenzen, kunming (china) seoul-incheon (s. korea); again, number flights rather limited.
as regard đà nẵng, i'm different forum; prefer base đà nẵng 2-3 weeks (rather hội an) - partially ride motorbike. centrally located day trip many interesting (and beaten path) places.

(these examples; need month two cover highlights đà nẵng, thừa thiên - huế, quảng nam, northern quảng ngãi).
cheers,
john
edited: 1:20 pm, 20,
column5:
hello nigel,
vân đồn is an international airport, but the number of routes is very limited as most of them are served by chartered flights; last i saw of a regular flight is to shenzhen, china.
from đà nẵng, you either fly into hanoi (nội bài airport - han) or hải phòng (cát bi airport - hph).
hải phòng is also an international airport, if you can connect in shenzen, kunming (china) or seoul-incheon (s. korea); again, the number of flights is rather limited.
as regard to đà nẵng, i'm different from most on this forum; i prefer to base out of đà nẵng with 2-3 weeks (rather than hội an) - partially because i can ride a motorbike. it's centrally located such that i can do a day trip to many interesting (and off the beaten path) places.

(these are just a few examples; you would need a month or two to cover just the highlights of đà nẵng, thừa thiên - huế, quảng nam, and northern quảng ngãi).
cheers,
john
edited: 1:20 pm, may 20, 2021

column4:
visa free visit asean countries thailand member. wife friends never asked proof funds insurance thailand.
if want visit place australia usa definitely need provide financial records, letter employment, family ties prove return vietnam issue visa.
the easiest costly way tour. tour agency able secure visa you.
i saw lots vietnamese part tour taipei airport every time flying vietnam.
column5:
it's visa free to visit asean countries in which thailand is a member. my wife and her friends were never asked about proof of funds or insurance for thailand.
if you want to visit a place like australia or usa then you will definitely need to provide financial records, letter of employment, family ties and other things to prove you'll return to vietnam before they issue a visa.
the easiest but more costly way would be to go on a tour. the tour agency will be able to secure a visa for you.
i saw lots of vietnamese who were part of a tour at the taipei airport every time i was flying into vietnam.

column5:
i think you are overthinking the situation. if you are that worried about missing a connecting flight to hiroshima, consider spending the 1st night in tokyo and continuing on the next day. after 12+ hours on an international flight, hanging out waiting for a connecting flight at the airport for a handful more hours isn't the most pleasant thing to do. go into the city and get a great meal, do a little sightseeing and get a good nights sleep, and take the short plane ride the next day.
if the open jaw ticket home>hiroshima, tokyo>home is prohibitively expensive, i would look at an open jaw ticket from home>osaka, tokyo>home and see what the prices look like. after flying into osaka, you could just take a shinkansen to hiroshima and not have to worry about missing or waiting around for a connecting flight.
edited: 5:21 pm, june 24, 2021

you specify flying from. normally, international flights landing tokyo narita (nrt) airport. nrt though, fewer domestic flights lack flights going hiroshima airport. current schedule shows operator low cost carrier can't combine leg international flight flies tokyo ticket. risk using separate ticket connection "unprotected." delays cause miss connection, work airline hiroshima find new flight, possibly cost.

to sum up:
1. buy two one-way tickets;
2. can't hiroshima connection using ticket, start trip tokyo. tokyo, train kyoto/osaka (2.5 hours). kyoto/osaka, train hiroshima (100 minutes). leaving hiroshima, see fly ticket connection. not, train tokyo. trip less rushed, stay couple days tokyo end trip departure;

column5:
most airlines actually offer you various options to fly into and out of different ports these days or via a connection if necessary. all can be booked on the same ticket so you don't have to buy two separate one-way tickets or worry about an unprotected connection.
you didn't specify where you are flying from. normally, there are more international flights landing at tokyo narita (nrt) airport. from nrt though, there are fewer domestic flights with a lack of flights going to hiroshima airport. the current schedule shows that the operator is a low cost carrier so you probably can't combine that leg with the international flight that flies into tokyo on the same ticket. the risk of using separate ticket is that your connection is "unprotected." if delays cause you to miss your connection, you will have to work with the airline to hiroshima to find a new flight, possibly at a cost.
if you can fly into tokyo haneda (hnd) though, then there are several flights daily to hiroshima so you might be able to make an immediate connection and put both flights onto the same ticket. that's the ideal situation. therefore, if you can't get both flights onto the same ticket, it's best to change your itinerary and start your trip visiting tokyo and then work your way to hiroshima by train.
to sum things up:
1. don't buy two one-way tickets;
2. if you can't get the hiroshima connection using the same ticket, then start your trip at tokyo. from tokyo, take the train to kyoto/osaka (2.5 hours). from kyoto/osaka, take the train to hiroshima (100 minutes). leaving hiroshima, see if you can fly out there with a same ticket connection. if not, just take the train back to tokyo. to make your trip less rushed, stay a couple of days at tokyo at the end of your trip before departure;
3. flying into/out of osaka is a viable option but the current flight schedule is much reduced so it might not work out. if things get back to normal, it's worth checking out.

column4:
scenarios involves ticket hiroshima tokyo home, skipping hiroshima tokyo segment. this; airline could cancel ticket breaking rules skip segment.
note tokyo two airports: narita (which chiba prefecture, far tokyo) haneda (in tokyo). avoid itinerary airports day.
an option fly narita, stay overnight airport hotel, leave next day train plane hiroshima. low-cost flights hiroshima leaving haneda narita; research this. daylight hours narita, old part town shrine easily reached airport. taking train could quite pleasant; narita express narita tokyo reserved seating (so overcrowded), shinkansen tokyo hiroshima worthwhile train experience.
column5:
one of your scenarios involves a ticket from hiroshima to tokyo to home, with you skipping the hiroshima to tokyo segment. do not do this; the airline could cancel your ticket for breaking their rules if you skip the first segment.
note that tokyo has two airports: narita (which is in chiba prefecture, far from tokyo) and haneda (in tokyo). avoid an itinerary where you have to use both airports in the same day.
an option would be to fly to narita, stay overnight an an airport hotel, and then leave the next day on a train or plane to hiroshima. but there may be more low-cost flights to hiroshima leaving from haneda than from narita; you'd have to research this. if you have some daylight hours in narita, the old part of town and the shrine are easily reached from the airport. taking the train could be quite pleasant; the narita express from narita to tokyo has all reserved seating (so it won't be overcrowded), and the shinkansen from tokyo to hiroshima is a worthwhile train experience.

column5:
>>there are no direct flights from my country to hiroshima. there are only connect flights through tokyo.
instead of the domestic flight, most of the people overlook the option of transiting via other east asian hubs such as seoul and taipei, which do offer routes to some smaller airports in japan. it is way better than transiting via tokyo as you do not need to worry baggage claim at transit point (as check through) and no immigration is needed for international-international transit. most important, you have very very low chance to have inter-airport transit which can be a nightmare (quite often when booking flights with nrt/hnd transit flights)
>>but then i realised, i would need a one-way ticket from my home country to hiroshima and then another one-way ticket from tokyo back home. what i didn't knew before that was, that a one-way ticket is way more expensive than a round trip ticket.
what you should look for is the "multi-city / multi-stop" option when booking the tickets on the airline official site. that allows you having the different arrival and departure cities within the same ticket (in a more professional term, open jaw ticket). mostly the ticket costs you more or less the same as a round trip.
>>first of all i thought about getting a round trip ticket from my home country to tokyo and book a separate ticket from tokyo to hiroshima. that's quite risky. if the tokyo flight is delayed the hiroshima one would not be refunded and i'd be stranded in tokyo with nothing booked and nothing prepared.
therefore we do always suggest people to have all flights booked into the same ticket so that you are protected if flight is delayed.
>>my second thought was booking a round way ticket from my home country to hiroshima, and because it connects in tokyo, on my way back i could just not bord the flight in hiroshima fland get on in tokyo. but i don't even know if that's possible/ allowed.
skipping legs will cause the cancellation of the remaining sectors. don't do that.

column5:
hi there,
i have been loosely planning a trip to tokyo for about a year. i want to travel there next spring (2022) as long as covid19 world allows.
my boyfriend and i both have terrible backs, and sitting in a seat for the long simply is not an option for either of us. the only way for us to do this trip is to fly business class / have the option to lay flat. i have chase sapphire preferred, and have been collecting my points, but at this rate, i will only have enough points to cover maybe half of one of our flights.
i see a lot of people suggesting buying economy tickets and going for an upgrade, but i really can't take the chance of not getting that upgrade, and then having to sit in the seats. i hope this does not come across as bratty, it is really just a physical limitation that we both have.
we are willing to fly out of any airport in the us (though we are based out of nyc). what is the cheapest way to do this?

column4:
#5,
all international flights land t3 - previously international terminal haneda (hnd). entering public area arrival floor, large bus ticket sales counter less 20m away buy limo bus tickets directly. bus stops level (ground floor) accessible large lifts. ticket staffs bus stop # direction unsure.

edited: 2:58 am, march 23,
column5:
#5,
all international flights land at t3 - previously the international terminal in haneda (hnd). after entering into the public area on the arrival floor, there is a large bus ticket sales counter in less than 20m away where you can buy limo bus tickets directly. the bus stops are on level 1 (ground floor) accessible by large lifts. ask the ticket staffs for the bus stop # and direction if unsure.
it's not a good idea to buy limo bus tickets in advance while overseas. should you cannot catch that bus - due to flight delays etc., the bus tickets would be void and you'd have to buy another one for the next bus.

column4:
andreas,
‘same ticket’ means flights booked pnr number.

if flights pnr, good need exit airport immigration japan.
if using travel agency, often, string together flights (which cheapest) separate pnr numbers. case, japan let board covid pandemic long term visa.
during pandemic, advice travel agency. buy tickets directly airline pnr.

column5:
andreas,
‘same ticket’ means all your flights are booked under one pnr number.

if both flights are under one pnr, then you are good to go and no need to exit the airport through immigration in japan.
if you are using a travel agency, they often, but not always string together a few flights (which are cheapest) under separate pnr numbers. if that is the case, japan will not let you board during covid pandemic without a long term visa.
during this pandemic, my advice is not to use a travel agency. buy tickets directly from an airline under one pnr.
also please note: if landing in narita, you must fly out from narita. if landing into haneda, you must fly out of haneda.
good luck!

column4:
commit plane tickets point. good chance sit vouchers, credit changeable flight ticket. options frustration keep money possibly months. book hotels require prepayment.
as itinerary, reference, relatively fast paced traveler many european driving trips experience. however, cannot possibly speed involves going destination daily spending multiple hours road. saying unhelpful, pace, none useful comments telling slow down. must incredible pace, unlikely experience offer guidance.
with weeks japan, skip okinawa, drop fukuoka hokkaido. see fukuoka hokkaido properly, need minimum 5-7 days *each*. also, understand places sapporo hakodate hokkaido about. visitors attracted natural scenery island. half october, focus country side see foliage, cities. hardly enough time see various sides tokyo osaka.
bottomline: less (transport time) (sightseeing time, real experience) us.
column5:
don't commit to plane tickets at this point. there is a good chance you might sit on vouchers, credit or a changeable flight ticket. all of those options would just mean frustration while they keep your money for possibly months. don't book any hotels that require prepayment.
as to your itinerary, for your reference, i am a relatively fast paced traveler with many european driving trips experience. however, i cannot possibly go at your speed which involves going to one destination daily and then spending multiple hours on the road. i am not saying this to be unhelpful, but at your pace, none of us can give you any useful comments other than telling you to slow down. if you must go at this incredible pace, it's unlikely any of us has such experience to offer you guidance.
with 3 weeks in japan, i would skip okinawa, then drop either fukuoka or hokkaido. to see fukuoka or hokkaido properly, you need a minimum of 5-7 days *each*. also, understand that places like sapporo and hakodate aren't really what hokkaido is about. visitors are attracted by the natural scenery of the island. during the first half of october, the focus should be on the country side to see foliage, not more cities. you hardly have enough time to see the various sides of tokyo or osaka.
bottomline: less (transport time) is more (sightseeing time, real experience) for most of us.

how a potential "vaccine passport" plays out in international travel (or even domestic travel for some countries) is unknown at this point. it's likely that wherever you intend to go, that country might not consider allow visitors to enter, or at least without quarantine, until a good percentage of their own population is vaccinated.
whatever you book, make sure it's not a prepaid rate. hotels do go out of business so you might not even get credit towards future stays. i wouldn't even book a plane ticket as one might be sitting on vouchers for months to years.

column4:
agree mm #6 l left bali considerable amount tourists around, mainly russians chose stay behind. international airport completely locked up, flight left via domestic airport jakata order clear immigration.
strangely walking jl bisma ubud two months seriously weird, l couldn’t believe amount construction gone l lockdown hotel end road. noted foreign tourists congregated southern beach areas, mainly canggu. generally lot scooters morning/ afternoons mostly locals.
i’m sure life normalised vaccine distributed throughout country / world.
column5:
absolutely agree with mm #6 when l left bali in may there was still a considerable amount of tourists around, mainly russians who chose to stay behind. the international airport was completely locked up, our flight left via the domestic airport to jakata first in order for us to clear immigration.
strangely walking up jl bisma in ubud after two months was seriously weird, l couldn’t believe the amount of construction that had gone on while l was in lockdown at my hotel at the end of the road. i noted most foreign tourists had congregated in the southern beach areas, mainly canggu. generally still a lot of scooters around in the morning/ afternoons which were mostly locals.
i’m sure life will only be normalised once a vaccine has been distributed throughout the country / world.

column5:
yes indeed let’s stick to the subject and the questions of the topic. whether we like it or not, indonesia is still closed for travelers and what we think how they should act is not relevant.
about the regulations: indonesia is closed for tourists and nobody knows when the country will reopen and what the policy will be.
about the possibility to meet your girlfriend there are two options.
- option 1
get a b211a business visa but at high costs and no guarantuee.
for the costs of the visa (through an agent), plus the 3 negative pcr-tests (1 before departure, 1 upon arrival in jakarta, 1 after the quarantaine), plus quarantaine in jakarta you must count on a minimum of 850 euro (but 1000 euro’s is more realistic) on top of your ticket. and maybe you also need another test when returning to france. also not very cheap (mid december around 150 euro’s).
the best options for a ticket are with qatar or emirates, in particular qatar who never stopped flying to/from jakarta since the outbreak last year.
but be aware: not sure everything will be ok, not sure if you can board the airplaine, not sure if you can pass immigration in jakarta.
yes there are a lot of succes stories but also a lot disappointments.
- option 2
like i suggested: get your girlfriend to france which is to my opinion far more realistic than the other way around. it’s also cheaper. for some reason tickets jakarta to europe are cheaper than europe to jakarta (which is normally the other way around). difference in price up to 200 euro’s. visa for france is also much cheaper. and when you girlfriend returns to indonesia she also is mandatory to do the pcr-tests and quarantaine but as an indonesian (i suppose she is indonesian) this is free of charge for her.
so this is a win win situation for you. less costs, less hassle.
otherwise just wait.

********************************************************************************************************************
travelers planning on flying to bali must first acquire a negative covid-19 pcr swab test issued within 48 hours prior to departure.
prior to departure to bali, every tourist must obtaining unique qr code by filling an application form. you can find the application form on this website: cekdiri.baliprov.go.id
visitors are required to take another pcr/ swab test upon arrival.
while waiting for the results (five days), visitors will be quarantined in appointed hotels, at their own cost.
on the fifth day of the quarantine, visitors must go through another pcr test, and if the results are negative, they may continue their journey.
********************************************************************************************************************
does anyone on the ground in bali have experience yet with this process? and do the pcr test results really take 5 days to receive?????
thanks in advance for anyone who can shed some light on this matter.

column5:
hi, agree not to plan nusa dua. agree sanur and ubud would be suitable. cycling is popular in sanur.
have a look at indonesia.tripcanvas.co>bali >family to get an overview of what’s on offer. kemenuh butterfly park is worthwhile. bali bird park and others mentioned above.
ubud is the area for cultural sightseeing and scenery.
choose your accommodation location wisely particularly in ubud. there is central ubud with cultural sites/monkey forest which are walkable (although i’ve not had a 5 y.o in tow). if staying further out check if your accommodation offers a complimentary shuttle service. use google maps. there is accommodation listed as ubud and miles from anywhere.
there are no metered taxis allowed in ubud. you will need a car with driver if staying further out with no shuttle service provided if wanting to wander around ubud centre.
metered taxis are available in sanur. again, important to check hotel location. do not choose over the other side of the bypass road.
my personal suggestion would be to stay in ubud first then sanur which is closer to the airport for your departure flight. choose an ubud based driver for your airport transfer and if the driver is compatible you can arrange your sightseeing trips with him and also your transfer to sanur.
if wanting accommodation recommendations you would need to state your budget.
as mentioned most aussies book everything ourselves. i personally choose booking.com for accommodation. be aware of your airline’s policy on refunds. i always choose the “free cancellation” option for our accommodation. our 2020 trip was cancelled and we received full refunds for all our bookings.
not sure what bali will hold for us when we are able to return. and as for november ...?
happy planning and hope you can travel in november.
cheers.
just saw your post regarding 3 locations. it’s doable if your family doesn’t mind unpacking, packing etc. note check in/check out times for each choice of accommodation. travel time in bali is slow. depending on your flight arrival it may take up to two hours + before arriving in ubud.
edited: 6:49 pm, february 25, 2021

column4:
steveprez,
you usgovt doesn’t authority stop people leaving country doesn’t people weren’t/are/will prevented leaving country.
my son company munich. 20 employees world. number usa, vietnam, brazil, uk well eu citizens. got new cto last year. american whose wife eu citizen. correct german documentation confirmation starting new job munich, rental contract place shipped furniture car wife kids refused boarding chicago. airline/airport service (not govt) interpreting german regulations. son ring foreign ministry germany contacted airline chicago put right allow family board. time happened airlines self-interpret countries regulations. sons employees, brit, home visiting parents uk xmas. tried fly xmas he, along many others, refused boarding. simply lufthansa interpreting german rules german passport holders rather german residents. son contact foreign ministry.
so isn’t govt says allow travel regulations country heading airline airport staffs interpretation country’s rules.
edited: 3:53 am, march 27,
column5:
hi steveprez,
you might think the usgovt doesn’t have the authority the stop people leaving the country but that doesn’t mean people weren’t/are/will be prevented from leaving the country.
my son has his own company in munich. he has over 20 employees from all over the world. a number from usa, vietnam, brazil, uk as well as some eu citizens. he got a new cto last year. an american whose wife is an eu citizen. although he had all the correct german and us documentation with confirmation that he was starting a new job in munich, already rental contract in place and shipped furniture and his car he and his wife and kids were refused boarding in chicago. this was the airline/airport service (not the govt) interpreting german regulations. my son had to ring the foreign ministry in germany who contacted the airline in chicago to put them right and to allow him and his family to board. this is not the first time it has happened where the airlines self-interpret a countries regulations. another one of my sons employees, a brit, was home visiting his parents in the uk just before xmas. when he tried to fly back before xmas he, along with many others, was refused boarding. simply lufthansa were interpreting the german rules as german passport holders rather than german residents. again my son had to contact the foreign ministry.
so it isn’t just what your own govt says even if they allow travel it is the regulations of the country you are heading to and the airline and airport staffs interpretation of that country’s rules.
edited: 3:53 am, march 27, 2021
column8: Are you allowed to travel from your country ?

column4:
question best answered travelers u.s.
recently, many suggestions open jaw tickets - fly japan city fly another. agree logistically, idea eliminates tracking.
however, never done every time checked, open jaw tickets carry big premium. least 50% additional, higher. beginning wonder whether missing something. (i open jaw points premium, issue cash fare)
so question u.s. travelers is, see open jaw premium vs roundtrip fare? able open jaw trips japan paying premium?
column5:
this question probably is best answered by travelers from the u.s.
recently, there have been many suggestions for open jaw tickets - fly into one japan city and fly out from another. i agree that logistically, it is a great idea as it eliminates back tracking.
however, i have never done it because every time i checked, open jaw tickets carry a big premium. it is at least 50% additional, sometimes higher. i am beginning to wonder whether i am missing something. (i do know i can do open jaw with points with no premium, so the issue is only with the cash fare)
so my question to other u.s. travelers is, do you see that same open jaw premium vs roundtrip fare? have you been able to do open jaw trips to japan without paying a premium?
column8: Open jaw fares from the U.S.

column4:
normal roundtrip open jaw, almost fares booking airlines, partner airlines, codeshare flights itinerary/ticket. pick flights 3rd party online travel agent (ota) randomly, expect pay more. exceptions could apply flying low cost carriers (lcc) price sector individually.
agree @bargainhunter airports used could influence prices. flying major hubs *usually* cheaper flights. also, math, compare additional flight cost vs additional train journey dollar time cost tokyo fly out. example, cost same, definitely choose flight open means connection via tokyo airport.
finally, covid likely messing airfares point. whether pricing pre-pandemic levels.
column5:
for both normal roundtrip and open jaw, you almost always get better fares by booking the same airlines, partner airlines, or codeshare flights under the same itinerary/ticket. if you pick flights off a 3rd party online travel agent (ota) randomly, expect to pay more. exceptions could apply if you are flying low cost carriers (lcc) where some price each sector individually.
agree with @bargainhunter above that airports used could influence prices. flying between major hubs *usually* give you cheaper flights. also, when you do the math, you can compare the additional flight cost vs an additional train journey dollar and time cost back to tokyo to fly out. for example, if both cost about the same, i would definitely choose the flight open even if it means a connection via a tokyo airport.
finally, covid is most likely messing up all airfares at this point. we don't know whether pricing will go back to pre-pandemic levels.
column8: Open jaw fares from the U.S.

column4:
thanks responses. made realize clear provide information questions.
yes, booked directly airlines. segments operated codeshare airlines, sold airlines itinerary. comparison try (1) simple roundtrip u.s. airport japan airport, (2) flying u.s. airport japan airport a, fly japan airport b u.s. airport open jaw airlines (3) simply book two way tickets. u.s. airport japan airport a, japan airport b u.s. airport. comparable, let's travel dates.
so found consistently (1) cheaper (2), (2) cheaper (3). (2) often 50% (1). roundtrip fare $1,300 example, open jaw closer $2,000.
so let's want fly nrt hnd, fly kix. open jaw cost 50% simple roundtrip hnd nrt. instead open jaw, fly kix hnd $120, shinkansen. waste half day that.
what want is, able find open jaw close price simple roundtrip japan. airports mentioned. seen comparable open jaw fly nrt fly japan airport, count.
column5:
thanks for all the responses. they made me realize i should have been more clear and provide more information in my questions.
yes, it will be booked directly with the same airlines. some segments may or may not be operated by codeshare airlines, but it will be sold by the same airlines and on one itinerary. the comparison i am try to make is between (1) simple roundtrip from one u.s. airport to one japan airport, (2) flying from one u.s. airport to japan airport a, and fly back from japan airport b to the same u.s. airport as an open jaw with the same airlines and (3) simply book two one way tickets. one from u.s. airport to japan airport a, and one from japan airport b back to the same u.s. airport. to make things comparable, let's use same travel dates.
so what i have found consistently is that (1) is cheaper than (2), and (2) is cheaper than (3). (2) is often 50% more than (1). so if a roundtrip fare is $1,300 as an example, an open jaw would be closer to $2,000.
so let's say i want to fly into either nrt or hnd, but fly back from kix. that open jaw will cost 50% more than a simple roundtrip in and out of hnd or nrt. instead of an open jaw, i can always fly from kix to hnd for around $120, or take the shinkansen. but i will waste half a day doing that.
what i want to know is, has anyone been able to find an open jaw that is close in price to a simple roundtrip between us and japan. it does not have to be between the airports i mentioned. so if anyone have seen a comparable open jaw that fly into nrt but fly out of another japan airport, that would count.
column8: Open jaw fares from the U.S.

column4:
reason of
1. flight kix washington dc iad (i assumed, closest international airport fairfax) full, expensive tickets available. dramatically increase open jaw ticket well, fare open jaw ticket usually calculated average round trip fare iad-tyo-iad iad-kix-iad case
2. promotion available iad tyo, open jaw routing allowed ticket. means original fare iad tyo iad kix round trip usd 1000 normal, airlines offer promotion iad - tyo - iad usd 500 rt, open jaw allowed. look open jaw ticket expensive.
maybe researching route + airlines + date dummy check? easier tell actual reason open jaw ticket expensive.
column5:
here are some reason that i can think of
1. the flight from kix to washington dc iad (i assumed, as that is the closest international airport from fairfax) are full, and only expensive tickets are available. that will dramatically increase the open jaw ticket as well, as the fare of open jaw ticket is usually calculated as average of round trip fare of iad-tyo-iad and iad-kix-iad in this case
2. promotion is available for iad to tyo, but open jaw routing is not allowed for such ticket. that means original the fare for iad to tyo or iad to kix round trip would be around usd 1000 in normal, but the airlines offer promotion for iad - tyo - iad of usd 500 rt, with no open jaw allowed. so that it will look like the open jaw ticket expensive.
maybe you can give us your researching route + airlines + date for us to have a dummy check? it will be easier for us to tell you the actual reason why the open jaw ticket is that expensive.
column8: Open jaw fares from the U.S.

column4:
primary airlines visits japan aa ua, ones researches on. aa code share jal ua code share ana. three international airports japan inbound u.s. non-stop flights hnd, nrt kix. three of. others, let expand searchs.
i looking fares two choices mentioned #7 above. open jaws higher, regardless dates. yes, flights full, push fare. tend push roundtrip open jaws time. fly three international gateway airports.
so want try dummy booking see, let's pick november 1, iad tyo leaving japan november 15 tyo roundtrip, kix open jaws.
and try december december 15 second test dates. expect results same, proportionally.
column5:
my primary airlines for visits to japan are aa and ua, and they are the ones i do researches on. aa code share with jal and ua code share with ana. the only three international airports in japan that have inbound u.s. non-stop flights are hnd, nrt and kix. those are the three i know of. if there are others, please let me know and i can expand my searchs.
i am looking at the fares between the first two choices i mentioned in #7 above. open jaws are always higher, regardless of the dates. yes, if the flights are full, that can push up the fare. but they tend to push up both roundtrip and open jaws a the same time. i can also fly in and out any of the three international gateway airports.
so if you want to try a dummy booking to see, let's pick november 1, 2021 from iad into tyo and leaving japan on november 15 from tyo as roundtrip, and from kix as open jaws.
and we can try december 1 to december 15 as the second test dates. i expect the results will be the same, proportionally.

column4: check introductory bonus point offers credit cards www.thepointsguy.com. willing lot research, willing read endless terms conditions, shy cancelling cards exploited bonus offers, enough airline points avoid paying cash plane tickets japan. order meet minimum spending requirements introductory bonus, credit card pay (or prepay) recurring bills, charitable contributions, medicare premiums, etc. standard trip fly tokyo, way via train kyushu, load ceramics arita, fly home fukuoka airport. using points, fukuoka flight "price" tokyo flight.
column5: check the introductory bonus point offers on credit cards at www.thepointsguy.com. if you're willing to do a lot of research, willing to read endless terms and conditions, and not shy about cancelling cards after you've exploited their bonus offers, you might get enough airline points to avoid paying cash for your plane tickets to japan. in order to meet minimum spending requirements to get the introductory bonus, you can use a credit card to pay (or prepay) recurring bills, charitable contributions, medicare premiums, etc. my standard trip is to fly to tokyo, make my way via train to kyushu, load up on ceramics from arita, and fly home from fukuoka airport. using points, the fukuoka flight is the same "price" as the tokyo flight.

column5:
>> transiting through any country outside the u.s. will just add time, and add potential headache from flight delays.
one of transit ports that can be considered is seoul, and i think you should put it in your consideration as well. apart from the reasons i have mentioned in former posts, here are some great points for transiting at icn
1. lots of flights to tokyo and osaka and the transit time is not that bad.
2. location-wise - it is right next to japan, so traveling time to seoul from tyo or kix is similar as traveling on domestic flight in japan. same for the long haul legs
3. flights to/from seoul seldom delay
4. icn offers free shower for transit pax + various selection of food, and it is a great refresh after/before the long haul flight
5. no visa issue as you don't need any transit visa at seoul, and us passport holders can enter south korea visa-free
>>the shortest distance between u.s. and japan is from our west coast to japan.
i think that should be going via north pole for west-bound flight should be the shortest way, while via west coast for east-bound flight to make use of the westerlies. lol

column4:
tourist, nothing worry about. years, strange incident wheen man (in suit, less) lining behind ticket machine started impatient cursed sorts names.
>>>was briefly concerned countries' history making difficult
takayama: try invest least 2-3 days area. add transport time tokyo takayama, takayama kyoto, takes almost whole day. therefore, want spend time transport investment pay off. minimum, 1/2 day trip shirakawago. add day 1.5 days, head kyoto via kanazawa.
kyoto/osaka: 4/2 night split, way whether worth moving around. alternatively, stay kyoto nights day trip osaka. move osaka, night stay visit nara there.
flying hiroshima: sure check outbound flight availability. normal times, hiroshima serves international destinations parts asia. uk, need transit somewhere. likely flight choices flying within japan domestically connecting tokyo. note tokyo osaka two airports. intend day connection, sure flights airport. book flights ticket protect connection guarantee through-checking bags.
column5:
as a tourist, you will have nothing to worry about. through the years, i have only had one strange incident wheen a man (in a suit, no less) lining up behind me at a ticket machine started to get impatient and cursed me all sorts of names.
>>>was briefly concerned about the countries' history making things difficult
takayama: try to invest at least 2-3 days in the area. when you add transport time from tokyo to takayama, then takayama to kyoto, it takes almost a whole day. therefore, you want to spend a bit more time to make the transport investment pay off. at a minimum, take a 1/2 day trip to shirakawago. if you can add another day to 1.5 days, head to kyoto via kanazawa.
kyoto/osaka: with a 4/2 night split, you can go either way as to whether it's worth moving around. alternatively, just stay in kyoto for all those nights and then take a day trip to osaka. if you move to osaka, maybe make it a 3 night stay and visit nara from there.
flying out from hiroshima: make sure you check outbound flight availability. during normal times, hiroshima serves a few international destinations to other parts of asia. to go back to the uk, you will need to transit somewhere. you will likely have the most flight choices flying within japan domestically and then connecting at tokyo. note that both tokyo and osaka have two airports. if you intend to make a same day connection, make sure both flights use the same airport. you should also book both flights on the same ticket to protect your connection and guarantee through-checking of bags.
